loans.name: Shaal

texts.en:
Shaal P. is 37. He is married and has 9 children. The family has lived in Shewa district of the Ningarhar province, which is an agricultural area, for a long time. Five of his children are studying in a public school but besides their schooling, they help their father with the farming part time .

Shaal P. has spent 12 years in farming. Prior to that, he worked as a shopkeeper in his village but the business did not support his family as much as they needed. So P. changed his business and now he is growing different kinds of vegetables on his land.

Shaal is a hard-working man. He wants to buy some livestock, too, because he thinks that he has a lot of grasslands in his village, and he can pick up good profit from them. He says that if he sells milk and yogurt, he will be able to solve all his financial problems. Through that he will provide all stationery or other necessary things for his children, also he will able to take care of his family’s health situation. But Shaal says that all these things depend to his income. Because his current daily income is just about 400 Afghanis ($8), it’s too difficult to make ends meet. Shaal decided to buy some livestock and increase his income through having it, but he doesn’t have much capital on hand for this purpose. So he has requested a loan in the amount of 30,000 Afghanis (US$ 650) from AFSG.

Shaal P. cares deeply about his children’s future, and he dreams of seeing them educated in the future. He says, "I can accept all problems for this goal, but I will never let them leave off studying." Also, he already thanks lenders for their great help.

loans.use: To buy some livestock

loans.name: Chheourn

texts.en: Mrs. Chheourn K. lives in the Trapang Cheksa Village, Kampong Chhnang Province. She earns income selling vegetables that she grows herself. Her husband, Mr. Dim Yoem, is a fish seller in the local market. The couple has a child who is still too young to work or study. Although Mrs. Chheourn K. and her husband run two businesses, they still cannot afford to hire construction workers to build a new house. Therefore, Mrs. Chheourn K. has decided to ask for a loan from AMK for this purpose.

loans.use: Hire of construction workers to build a new house

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
Muhammad H. is 45 and the father of six children. He lives with his family in Shewa district. The household renturned from Pakistan after living 15 years as refugees there. Mr. H. is teaching in a public school in his village. He has enrolled his sons in school. His eldest son is 18 and now is the 10th grade.

Even though Mr. H. is teaching, he is farming in his land part time. He has a half acre of land near his house, and grows various vegetables in different seasons. Right now he grows corn in his lands.

Mr. H. likes teaching more than farming, but he can’t solve his financial problems with his $50 a month salary. He had complaints that they could not buy fruit for a week for his family; likewise he cannot provide stationery or other essential goods for his sons easily.

However, Mr. H. has not lost hope. He wants to remedy his situation by taking out a 50,000 Afghanis loan (US$ 1075) from AFSG. Muhammad H. believes that by purchasing some livestock with this loan, he can solve 50% of his problems; he will sell milk and yogurt in the bazaar and in his village.P> Mr. H. dreams of one day providing all facilities for his sons’ education so that he can present educated individuals for society. Also, he is already thankful to the kind lenders.

loans.use: To buy livestock

loans.name: Yim

texts.en: Mrs. Yim M. lives in the Prey Khmer Village, Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a housewife who stays at home and cooks food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Korng Prak, is a taxi-driver whose income is very low. The couple has three children who are still too young to work or study. The family currently lives in an old house; therefore, Mrs. Yim M. needs a loan to combine with her savings for construction of a new house.

loans.use: Construction of a house

loans.name: Navy

texts.en: Mrs. Navy N., 40 years old, lives in the Lboeuk Village, Kampong Chhnang Province, with her husband, Mr. Kosal Em, who transports soil for sale in the village. The couple does not have any children. Mrs. Navy N. earns income breeding pigs. Since her business is going well, she would like to expand it. Therefore, Mrs. N. is asking for a loan to be able to purchase additional piglets and food to feed them.

loans.use: Purchase of piglets and animal feed

loans.name: Kea

texts.en: Mrs. Kea E. earns income selling fruit in the local market located in the Kan Yuo Village, Kampong Chhnang Province. Aside from this business, she also breeds pigs. Her second business is going well, and, therefore, Mrs. Kea E. would like to expand it. She is asking for a loan to buy additional piglets and food to feed them. Mrs. Kea E. has already previously obtained a loan, which she used to start her fruit sale business and then successfully paid back.

loans.use: Purchase of piglets and animal feed

loans.name: Savorn

texts.en: Mrs. Savorn C. lives in the Spork Reach Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She earns income working as a thatch seller. Mrs. C. obtained a loan from AMK to start her business and has fully paid it back. Since her business now is doing well, Mrs. Savorn C. wants to expand it and is therefore asking for a loan to buy more thatches to re-sell. She is 48 years old and has a son who works as a construction worker. Mrs. C.'s husband, Mr. Sameourn Pun, is a farmer. Last year, Mr. Sameourn Pun fell sick with a liver disease, and Mrs. Savorn C. spent US$300 for his treatment. This is part of the reason why Mrs. Savorn C. currently needs to borrow money for the purchase of additional thatches.

loans.use: Purchase of thatches for sale

loans.name: Uguloy

texts.en:
Uguloy M. is a 44-year-old widow with three children. She loves her children very much and does all she can to keep them happy and smiling. Thirteen years ago, she started her own business because she needed extra income to pay for children's expenses, and their home and medical care.

Uguloy enjoys selling, and her business has done well. Her older daughter, seen in the photo, helps run the company. Uguloy has a very good taste and is ready to advise her clients about which fabric will work best for this or that occasion. Moreover, Uguloy’s prices are attractive for many kinds of people and income levels. She is applying for a loan of $300 to expand her business and will repay it within four months. Uguloy will use the income generated by the loan to improve her family's living conditions. She extends her thanks to everyone who trusts her by funding the loan, and promises to repay in a timely manner.

loans.use: To buy new fabric to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Nasibakhon

texts.en:
Nasibakhon H. is 32 years old, married and the loving mother of four children. For the last eight years, she has made a living selling children's and women's clothing from a stand located in an especially busy part of town.

She started out with only a few products, but her business has grown thanks in part to help from her husband, who acquires goods for her to sell from a neighboring town. Today, Nasibakhom is able to make a large contribution to the family budget. To continue to do that, she has applied for a loan of $750 to expand the range of items she has to sell. She plans to repay the loan in nine months, promises to make payments on time and thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: To buy additional clothing to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Sabohatoy

texts.en:
Sabohatoy M. is 49 years old, married and has four children. She makes a living as a vendor, selling clothes and shoes for children. She has been in this business for 13 years, and her ability to pick out items her customers will like and buy has allowed her to build a stable and successful business. With the help of her husband, she gets goods in the neighboring town of Dushanbe. She aims to buy good-quality items that she can sell at a price which is acceptable to customers with average incomes. Thanks to her success, Sabohatoy is able to contribute considerable sums to the family budget and help her husband support his parents as well as their family.

Sabohatoy is looking for late-summer items to sell to her customers. To make this possible, she has applied for a loan of $1,000 which she will repay in 12 months. She hopes this loan will increase her income and allow her to send her daughter to college. Sabohatoy promises to make payments on time and thanks everyone for supporting her.

loans.use: To buy new clothes and shoes for children to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Mayram

texts.en:
Mayram T. is the 44-year-old mother of two children. Because her husband was not able to find work locally, he has left for Russia to find a job there. Mayram and her husband are determined to work hard to get ahead and ensure a good future for their children. For the last 12 years, Mayram has run her own business selling shoes. As she has become more involved in her work, she has even begun dreaming of opening up her own store.

Today, she sells shoes for teenagers and men in a store located in her town's central market. Mayram is a friendly and polite woman, and is trying to diversify the range of goods she has to sell so that she can satisfy the needs of clients with various levels of income. Her business is doing well, and Mayram is able to make a considerable contribution to her family's budget, but her children are growing up and expenses are rising. She wants to expand her business to meet the needs of her children. To make this possible, she is seeking a loan for $1,000 to buy late-summer shoes to sell. She will repay the loan within four months. Mayram thanks everyone who supports her, and promises to repay this loan in the same manner that she has repaid previous ones.

loans.use: To buy new goods to sell to her customers

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Ms. Farida is 20 years old and single. She lives with her family including her mother and two small brothers who are school boys. She lost her father during the war in Afghanistan, so she holds all the responsibilities for the family and has presently lots of economic problems.

Farida has a bakery in her house. All her clients are female. She needs to open a bigger one through which she could do her business better, meeting the expenses of her poor family.

When Farida found about AFSG, she requested an individual loan to improve her business. By expanding her business, she should be able to better support her family.

Farida is very happy with the process of loans in Afghanistan, especially the programs for women who are responsible for their families. Farida wants to thank all lenders around the world and AFSG in advance.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Edna's Malaika Group

texts.en:
Edna is 33-years-old, married and has four children, ages 18, 11, 8 and 2. She began selling clothes and cosmetics in 2003. She works from 8AM to 12PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Edna now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes and cosmetics items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with tailoring, shop ownership, fish and tomatoes sales, clothes sales, and rice and vegetable sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and cosmetics items for resale

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Un T., 26, is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She and her husband work together making mortars and pestles and selling them to brokers who normally come their base twice a week. Un T. and her husband buy raw material like stone in bulk from the vendors in a nearby village and start designing and making good quality and pestle and mortars. This couple can typically make around $5 per day of net income.

In order to meet their growing customer demands, this couple would like to request a loan from KIVA to purchase more stone and some tools accelerate their work.

loans.use: To purchase more stone to produce motars and pestles

loans.name: Nasibakhon

texts.en:
Nasibakhon A. is 40 years old, married and has three children. Her husband is in the military and her oldest son goes to college. Nasibakhon makes a living as a market vendor. She went into business because she wanted to get ahead, and her husband´s salary was not enough cover household expenses. Her company sells clothing for children, and she has been in this business for the last three years.

When Nasibakhon began her company, it was worth about $100, but currently she has about $1,000 in working capital. With help from her oldest son, she gets goods in the neighboring town of Istaravshan. She is trying to diversify the range of items she has to sell so that she can satisfy the needs of clients with various levels of income. Growing her business would also allow Nasibakhon to provide the best possible future for her children and ensure they get a good education. To make all this possible, she is seeking a $600 loan which she will pay back in nine months. Nasibakhon thanks all who support her and promises to pay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To buy additional children's clothing to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Prak

texts.en: Mrs. Prak P., 46, is a widow with one child who is a student. She works selling traditional medicine, which is normally made from herbs and other grass. She sells her medicine from place to place around her town, making typically about $5 per day in revenue. Mrs. Prak P. would like to take out the loan to purchase a motor-bike to use for her business transportation. As now she has only a bicycle to transport her medicine.

loans.use: To buy a motor-bike to use for her busines transportation

loans.name: Mahsuda

texts.en:
Mahsuda E. is 31 years old, married and has one son. She makes a living as a market vendor, selling shoes for girls and women. She has been in this line of work for four years, and has done well because she knows which items are going to be the most popular with her customers. Thanks to her success, Mahsuda is able to contribute quite a bit to the family budget and help her husband support his family and parents.

Mahsuda would like to buy new shoes for girls and women to sell in the late summer months. To do this, she needs additional funds, and has applied for a loan of $600 that she will repay in nine months. Mahsuda promises to make payments faithfully, and thanks everyone who chooses to support her because the loan will allow her to make better use of her shop's location and offer more goods to sell. She will use her increased income to ensure that her son can continue in school and have a bright future.

loans.use: to buy more shoes to sell.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline, 38, is a married woman with three children, ages 13, 10 and 4. She became a tailor in 2002. She works from 8AM to 12PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

Pauline now hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items for improving the business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 27-years-old, married with two children, ages 12 and 8. She has been selling cement and chickens since 2006. She works from 8AM to 6PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $100 from her sales.

Mary now hopes for a loan to buy more cement for her business.

loans.use: To buy more cement to increase her stock.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.en:
Muhabbat N. is 45 years old, married and has two children. Her husband is an economist. Muhabbat opened her own general store four years ago because good jobs were not available and she wanted to make sure that her family had enough money to meet its needs. This business is one of her greatest accomplishments because she has always dreamed of owning a business and not having to depend on anyone else.

Muhabbat's company sells clothing to children and women. From time to time, she travels to the neighboring town of Istaravshan to buy goods to sell. Her younger son, pictured here, helps out in the business. Muhabbat started out with only a few products, but her business has grown larger and more stable. Thanks to hard work by Muhabbat and her husband, her daughter was able to get married last year. Now, they are focused on giving their son a good education so that he has the best possible future. That is why Muhabbat has applied for a loan of $1,000 to expand her business. She will repay the loan in nine months. She promises to repay it faithfully, as she has done in the past with previous loans, and wishes to thank the people who choose to support her.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Hamidullo

texts.en:
Hamidullo M. is 29 years old, married and has three children. He has been a farmer for his whole life and now specializes in growing rice. He has 12 years experience in this field, and has been able to support his family by carefully tending and managing his crops in a short growing season. Each year, Hamidullo grows enough rice for the family to eat and to sell. His wife, seen here in the photo, helps Hamidullo sell their rice, generate a stable income and support their family.

Hamidullo has applied for a loan of $600, which he will pay back in nine months. He will use this loan to buy supplies for his farm and improve production, thereby increasing the quality of his yield and his income. Hamidullo thanks everyone for supporting him and promises to repay the loan faithfully.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Rahmatullo

texts.en:
M. Rahmatullo is 28 years old. He and his wife, a housekeeper, are raising two children. Rahmatullo’s children are small now, but he is already working hard to ensure the best possible future for them. He makes a living selling foodstuff like pastries, cookies, candies, condensed milk, tea, caned meat, mayonnaise and other items in a store which he rents. Rahmatullo has been in this business for seven years. He is very polite and his store is very popular with local residents, whose patronage allows him to earn a good income for his family.

Rahmatullo has applied for a loan of $600 due in nine months, and will use the loan to buy more items to sell. This will allow him to earn more and meet the needs of his family. Rahmatullo thanks everyone for their support and promises to repay the loan in time.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in his grocery store.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 29-years-old, married with two children, ages 10 and 6. She began selling shoes and clothes in 2006. She works from 10AM to 8PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

Mary now hopes for a loan to buy more shoes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose, 32, is a married woman with two children, ages 7 and 6. She owns a grocery store which she started in 2005. She works from 8AM to 9PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

Rose now hopes for a loan to buy more soda for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items like soda to increase inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Marhabo

texts.en:
S. Marhabo is 39 years old, widowed and the mother of two children. After the death of her husband, Marhabo had to find ways to provide for herself and her family. For 11 years, she has run a business baking and selling the national bread, lepeshka. It has become a family business, with her now grown children helping her.

Marhabo is a cheerful and hard-worker despite the difficulties she faces. She has received and repaid two loans from IMON, each of which helped create stability for her business. Today, Marhabo is applying for a loan of 3,400 Somoni ($1,000 USD) due in 12 months. She will use it to buy coal and flour for baking. This will allow her to increase her sales and earn more so she can provide her children with a good education. With your help, this will be possible.

loans.use: To buy coal and flour to bake the national bread, lepeshka.

loans.name: Fridah's Rehema Group

texts.en:
Fridah is a 37-year-old widow with two children, ages 10 and 17. She owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2007. She works from 8AM to 11PM and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Fridah has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more crates of beer and soda for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with fish sales, food sales, grocery stores and vegetable sales.

loans.use: To more crates of beer and soda to increase sales

loans.name: You

texts.en: Mrs. You S., 54, has a stand at home selling Khmer noodle soup and porridge to the people in her area, making on average about $2/day of net income. She started this business in 1998. Her husband is a farmer growing rice and vegetables on his farm land, typically earning around $1 per day in revenue. One of her children is now employed as a garment worker, another two are construction workers and the rest are married and live outside the family home. Mrs. You S. would like to request a loan from KIVA to purchase two cows to assist in plowing farmland.

loans.use: Purchase two cows to assist in plowing

loans.name: Amina's Rehema Group

texts.en:
Amina is 28-years-old, married with two children, ages 11 and 4. She began selling food in 2000. She works from 6AM to 9PM and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Amina has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items and utensils for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with groceries, cooking oil sales, alcohol and vegetable sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items and utensils for her business.

loans.name: Rit

texts.en:
Mrs. Rit S., 21, sells chickens that she buys from family raisers in her village and resells for a profit. She has been selling chickens since 2005 and makes around $5 per day. Her husband, Mr. Tin Ten, 21, is a farmer who farms in two seasons, rainy and dry. He earns around $4 per day. They live with their one child in Sampor Village, Kampong Thom Province. Because of the difficulty to transport chickens for sale, S. is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a second-hand motorcycle to use for her chicken business. The loan will allow her to improve her business and increase the family’s income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase a second-hand motorcycle to use for her chicken sales

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith, 37, is a divorced woman with three children, ages 18, 15 and 11. She also takes care of one other child who is two months old. She began selling clothes in 1999. Judith works from 8AM to 8PM and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Judith has taken out two successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes and shoes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and shoes for resale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Vicky is a 30-year-old married woman with two children aged 9 and 5. She became a fish and clothes seller in 2003. She works from 9AM to 6PM each day and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Vicky has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more fish and clothes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fish and clothes for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Uria's Mapinduzi Group

texts.en:
Uria, 41, is a married woman with two children, ages 13 and 5. She sells food from 6AM to 10PM and can earn a monthly profit of about $62 from her sales.

Uria has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who has business selling clothing.

loans.use: To purchase food items  to increase sales

loans.name: Kesia

texts.en:
Kesia, 38, is a married woman with five children, ages 19, 17, 12, 6 and 1. She became a millet and cakes seller in 1996. She works from 6AM to 8PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Kesia has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more millets, cooking oil and wheat flour cakes for her business.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of millets, cooking oil and wheat flour cakes

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Pan

texts.en:
Mr. Pan H., 53, is a farmer as well as veterinarian in his village and earns around $5 per day. His wife, Mrs. Ea Sok, 47, is a farmer and earns around $3 per day. Together they have five children and live in Rokar Village, Kampong Thom Province. In order to expand their farming business, H. is requesting a loan of US$ 600 to purchase two oxen to use for their farming business. The loan will allow him to expand the farming business and increase the family’s income through reducing the cost of oxen rental.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase two oxen to use for his farming business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 33-years-old and married with two children, ages 17 and 15. She began selling clothes in 2006. She works from 8AM to 6PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Jane has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes and she want to open a new business (kiosk).

loans.use: To buy more clothes and open a kiosk

loans.name: Fransica

texts.en:
Fransica is a 32-year-old married woman with two children, ages 13 and 6. She began selling clothes in 2007. She works from 7AM to 6PM each day at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Fransica now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Aziza's Ujamaa Group

texts.en:
Aziza is 35-years-old, married and has four children, ages 18, 15, 8 and 5. She began selling food and owning livestock in 2000. She works from 6AM to 5PM each day at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Aziza has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Aziza now hopes for a loan to buy more cows and other utensils for her food sales business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who also have businesses dealing with alcohol sales and milk sales.

loans.use: To purchase cows and additional utensils for food sales

loans.name: Rahel's Ujamaa Group

texts.en:
Rahel is 30-years-old, married with two children, ages 12 and 5. She began selling clothes in 2002. She works from 8AM to 6PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

Rahel has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business.She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes to increase her inventory. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who also have businesses dealing with shop ownership and milk sales.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothing for resale

loans.name: Faith's Hosana Group

texts.en:
Faith is a 26-year-old single woman. She began selling clothes in 2006. She works from 10AM to 6PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Faith now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with clothes sales and carpets sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. cooks rice to sell to her costumers. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Felicia and her 2 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana Q. sells Banku, a local meal, which she prepares for sale. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Diana and her 2 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Sweet's Hosana Group

texts.en:
Sweet is 24-years-old, married with three children between the ages of two and five. She began selling clothing in 2007. She works from 8AM to 6PM and earns a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Sweet now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes and shoes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with salon ownership and carpets sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and shoes for a clothing shop.

loans.name: Rose's Hosana Group

texts.en:
Rose is 25-years-old, married with three children, ages 8, 5 and 10 months. She became a fish and chips seller in 2007. She works from 7AM to 10PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80.

Rose now hopes for a loan to purchase more fish and to start a new business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with grocery stores and food sales.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to increase inventory for resale

loans.name: Zabibu's Hosana Group

texts.en:
Zabibu is 33-years-old, married and has three children, ages 13, 10 and 2. She began selling chicken in 2007. She works from 8AM to 6PM each day at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Zabibu now hopes for a loan to buy more chicken for her business and to start a new business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with food sales and carpets sales.

loans.use: To purchase more chicken for resale

loans.name: Thi Nguyen's Group

texts.vi:
Ms. P. Thi N., born in 1951, wants to borrow 4,876,000VND (equivalent to 295USD) to sell food at the market. Her husband passed away, leaving her with their young children at Luc Canh hamlet, Xuan Canh, Dong Anh province, Hanoi. With the average monthly income of 1,500,000VND (equivalent to 95USD), Ms. N. is still having a hard time to make ends meet and provide schooling for her children. She would like to take this loan from SEDA (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) to invest in her business and improve her current condition. Her group of borrowers includes:

L. Thi Thu, born in 1966, would like to borrow 3,604,000 VND (equivalent to 217USD) to raise pigs.

N. Kim Hoa, born in 1967, would like to borrow 3,596,000 VND (equivalent to 217USD) to raise chicken.

D. Thi Hop, born in 1970, would like to borrow 3,596,000 VND (equivalent to 217USD) to sell clothes at the market.

H. Thi Lan, born in 1969, would like to borrow 1,060,000 VND (equivalent to 65USD) to buy some cows.

C. Thi Minh, born in 1967, would like to borrow 3,596,000 VND (equivalent to 217USD) to sell vegetabL. at the market.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong N., Kiva Volunteer.

Phạm Thị Nguyên, sinh năm 1951(Ms 23010063), mức vay: 4.876.000 vnđ để đi chợ bán đồ ăn. Chồng cô đã mất, hiện cô đang sống cùng các cháu tại thôn Lực Canh, Xuân Canh, Đông Anh, Hà Nội. Với thu nhập bình quân khoảng 1.500.000 vnđ / tháng, cộng với việc nuôi các cháu ăn học, kinh tế gia đình cô còn eo hẹp. Cô mong muốn được vay vốn phát triển kinh tế để cải thiện mức sống hiện tại. Nhóm vay vốn D. cô làm nhóm trưởng gồm có: Lê Thị Thư, sinh năm 1966 (Ms 23010059), mức vay: 3.604.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn. Nguyễn Kim Hoa, sinh năm 1967 (Ms 23010058 ), mức vay: 3.596.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà. Đỗ Thị Hợp, sinh năm 1970 (Ms 23010065), mức vay: 3.596.000 vnđ để đi chợ bán hàng quần áo. Hoàng Thị Lan, sinh năm 1969 (Ms 23010060), mức vay: 1.060.000 vnđ để mua bò. C. Thị Minh, sinh năm 1967 (Ms 23010064), mức vay: 3.596.000 vnđ để đi chợ rau.

loans.use: breeding animals

loans.name: Dina's Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
Dina is 26-years-old, married and has two children, ages 18 and 12. She sells clothing and owns a farm, which she started in 2006. She works from 8AM to 8PM each day at her business, earning a monthly profit of approximately $80.

Dina has taken out one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more inventory for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with maize sales and clothing sales.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to increase inventory

loans.name: Thi My Quynh's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Thuy Quynh was born in 1985. She would like to borrow 1,972,000 VND (equivalent to 120 USD) to invest in raising pigs. Her husband is a worker, who earns about 1,500,000 VND per month (equivalent to 90 USD per month). Mrs. Quynh’s main job is to do farming at home, particularly to raise pigs. Currently, they have 3 pigs raised for meat. Mrs. Quynh is a team leader of her group of four other members, each of them wants to borrow a loan amount of 1,972,000 VND (equivalent to 120 USD): Ms. T. Thu Huong, born in 1983 to sell vegetable at the market; Ms. N. Thi Ut, born in 1980, to sell vegetable at the market; Ms. T. Thi Vu An, born in 1977, to invest in her general store; and Ms. N. Thi Thiet, born in 1964, to raise pigs.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong N., Kiva Volunteer.

Nguyễn Thị Thúy Quỳnh, sinh năm 1985(Ms 10030029 ), mức vay: 1.972.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn. Chồng chị là công nhân có thu nhập bình quân khoảng 1.500.000 vnđ / tháng. Chị chủ yếu ở nhà tăng gia sản xuất, chăn nuôi lợn. Hiện tại, vợ chồng chị đang nuôi 3 con lợn thịt.Chị là nhóm trưởng nhóm vay vốn. Trong nhóm chị gòm có: Trần Thị Thu Hương, sinh năm 1983(Ms 10030031 ), mức vay: 1.972.000 vnđ để đi chợ buôn bán rau. Nguyễn Thị Út, sinh năm 1980 (Ms 10030030 ), mức vay: 1.972.000 vnđ để đầu tư bán hàng tạp hóa. Trịnh Thị Vũ An, sinh năm 1977 (Ms 10030027 ), mức vay: 1.972.000 vnđ để đầu tư hàng tạp hóa. Nguyễn Thị Thiết, sinh năm 1964 (Ms 10030028 ), mức vay: 1.972.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn.

loans.use: chăn nuôi

loans.name: Theopista's Ushindi Group

texts.en:
Theopista is a married woman with 2 children aged 15 and 12. She became a vegetable seller in 2002. Every day, she works from 10am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Theopista now hopes for a loan to buy more vegetables for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with farms and clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for her business

loans.name: Lilian's Happy Group

texts.en:
Lilian is a married woman with 2 children aged 10 and 15. She became a clothes seller in 2008. Every day, she works from 10am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $45 from her sales.

Lilian now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with vegetable sales, clothes sales and a cafe.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Juliana's Harakati Group

texts.en:
Juliana is a married woman with 3 children aged 27, 22, and 11. She became a clothes seller in 2006. Every day, she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

In the past, Juliana has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business.Juliana now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes and to open a shop for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with groceries, milk sales, and clothes sales.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a married woman with 3 children aged 10, 8, and 6. She became a clothes seller in 2006. Every day, she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Alice now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Mirnesa

texts.en:
Mirnesa is a 22-year-old woman living near the town of Gračanica. She is married with 2 children, one who is just a month old, while her older child is 3. Her husband is currently employed and works installing glass windows in buildings.

This is Mirnesa’s third loan with Žene za Žene, which she is requesting in the amount of 1500 KM (US$ 1200). She has one cow, and she wants to buy another one. This time she plans to buy a pregnant cow, and after it gives birth she can sell the calf for a good profit. She will keep the mother cow to use for producing milk for sale.

The profit Mirnesa makes from the sale of the calf and the additional milk sales she hopes to have can go towards their home. They have been in the process of building it and still need furniture and some other items before it is complete.

loans.use: To buy a pregnant cow for milking and breeding

loans.name: Hava

texts.en:
Hava is a 48-year-old woman living near the town of Gračanica. She is married, but her husband is currently out of work. They have one son, who is grown and working abroad in Slovenia. Hava farms her land and raises cattle, and right now she has a cow and a heifer.

This is her 3rd loan with ŽZene za ŽZene, and Hava wishes to use this one to help build her barn. Right now it's constructed partly out of brick and partly with wood. Unfortunately, the wood part is old and falling apart. She wants to renovate the barn and build it completely without of brick in order to provide a safe home for her cows over the winter.

loans.use: To build a barn for her cows

loans.name: Anna's Harakati Group

texts.en:
Anna is a married woman with 2 children aged 10 and 7. She became a caterer in 2008. Every day, she works from 9am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

In the past, Anna has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Anna now hopes for a loan to buy dishes and chairs for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with clothes and vegetable sales.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Mwanamvua's Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Mwanamvua is a married woman with 3 children aged 18, 14, and 8. She became a vegetable seller in 2005. Every day, she works from 8am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $37 from her sales.

In the past, Mwanamvua has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Mwanamvua now hopes for a loan to buy more vegetables for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with vegetables and catering and timber sales.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for her business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 22 years old. She is a single woman. She became a hair designer in 2002. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Josephine now hopes for a loan to open a salon for her business.

loans.use: To open a salon for her business

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza is 24 years old. She is a single woman. She became a clothes seller in 2008. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

Aziza now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Happiness

texts.en:
Happiness is 34 years old. She is a divorced woman with 3 children aged 15, 13, and 8. She became a clothes seller in 2002. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

In the past, Happiness has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Happiness now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Arafa

texts.en:
Arafa is 31 years old. She is a married woman with 2 children aged 11 and 5. She became a food seller in 1997. Every day, she works from 6am to 3pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

In the past, Arafa has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Arafa now hopes for a loan to buy more food items such as rice, maize flour, meat, vegetables, and bananas for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items to increase her stock

loans.name: Frida

texts.en:
Frida is a divorced woman with 1 child aged 17. She became a drinks and clothes seller in 2008. Every day, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

Frida now hopes for a loan to buy more drinks items and clothes for her business.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Happy's Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Happy is a married woman with 2 children aged 7 and 4. She became a caterer and vegetable seller in 2006. Every day, she works from 6am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

In the past, Happy has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Happy now hopes for a loan to buy more vegetables for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with maize sales and clothes sales.

loans.use: To more vegetables for her business

loans.name: Martha's Hekima Group

texts.en:
Martha is a married woman with 7 children between 10 and 36. She also takes care of 2 other children aged 6 and 4 years old. She became a maize and milk seller in 1998. Every day, she works from 7:30am to 6:30pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Martha now hopes for a loan to buy more maize and milk for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with banana sales, beans, and maize sales.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Ekaeli's Akanga Group

texts.en:
Ekaeli is 27 years old. She is a married woman with 2 children aged 5 and 1. She became a banana seller in 2003. Every day, she works from 8:30am to 6:30pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Ekaeli now hopes for a loan to buy more bananas for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with banana sales, and shops and vegetable sales.

loans.use: To buy more bananas for her business

loans.name: Kateba Group

texts.en:
This group of 3 named their group Kateba. Their names are: John K., Kadiatu S. and Adamsay K.. John K. is the leader of the group. He was born in Makeni 42 years ago. He is married with 4 children. He is a tailor and has been in this business for over 20 years now. He sews and sells clothes. He would like to use his loan to buy materials, threads, zippers, buttons, etc.

Kadiatu S. gets most of the produce she sells from "lumas" (mobile business centres). She buys goods that are available cheap at the lumas. Most often, the goods she buys and sells are palm-oil, rice, groundnuts etc.

Adamsay K. sells ground nuts, peppers, and rice. All of these businesspeople will use their loans to add to their current businesses.

Previous loans have helped them a lot. John was able to buy a new sewing machine with previous loans. Both Kadiatu's and Adamsay's businesses have greatly increased in size, and profit has thus increased. Ultimately, this has led to an improvement in the family's livelihood. However, it is continuous access to loans that can eradicate or at least reduce poverty. Thus, the Kateba group is still requesting a new loan of Le 2,400,000 to further empower their businesses.

loans.use: Buy materials, threads, zippers, and buttons to add to his business.

loans.name: Maria Helena

texts.pt:
Maria Helena M. is 63 years old and a native of Maputo. A widow, she is the mother of seven children aged 41, 39, 37, 34, 27, 25, and 23. Two of them live in their own houses. In addition to her children, she lives with one daughter-in-law. She lives in her own house.

Maria studied through fourth grade and stopped because the fees rose to a point that her family could not afford to pay. Maria worked at many companies, and the last, until her retirement, was the Ministry of Defense.

Maria is retired from the Ministry of Defense with a monthly pension of 3,600 meticals. Beyond her retirement she raises and fattens chickens to increase the family income. This is Mrs. M.’s second loan in life, the first also with Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner).

The loan of 12,000 meticals will be used to purchase construction material to improve the family residence.

Her big dream is to buy a vehicle for the family to use and to help sell the chickens.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer.

Maria Helena M. tem 63 anos de idade e é natural de Maputo, Viuva e mae de 7 filhos com idades entre 41; 39; 37; 34; 27; 25 e 23 anos respectivamente. Dois destes já vivem nas suas casas. Para alem dos filhos vivem com uma nora.

Maria estudou até 4ª classe e parou porque a família não tinha condições para pagar o internamento uma vez que na zona onde viviam o nível ia até este. Maria trabalhou em muitas empresas e em ultimo até a sua reforma foi no ministério da defesa. Vive numa casa propria.

Maria é reformada do ministério da defesa com uma pensão mensal de 3.600,00MT. Para alem da reforma ela faz criacao de frangos de engorde para aumentar a renda familiar. Este é o segundo empréstimo na vida da dona Maria e sempre com Hluvuku.

O emprestimo de 12.000,00MT vai ser aplicado na compra de material de construcao para melhoramento da residencia familiar.

Tem como grande sonho comprar uma viatura para uso familiar e ajuda na comercializacao dos frangos.

loans.use: To buy material to improve her family’s house

loans.name: Maria De Lurdes

texts.pt:
Maria de Lurdes J. is 49 years old and a native of the Inhambane Province in the south of Mozambique. She is divorced and the mother of two children, 28 and 30 years old. She supports her mother and a granddaughter, periodically sending them money.

She studied through ninth grade, when we stopped and got married. She lived with her parents during childhood until 1976, when she completed seventh grade. Then because of a lack of further schooling options she had to move away from her home province to the city of Maputo, where she continued her studies in her brother’s house. Two years later she met the man who became her husband and the father of her two children. She lives in her own house.

Maria is an employee of the Ministry of Health and has worked in a health center in the city of Maputo since 1999. Her hours are from 7:30am to 3:30pm, and her salary is 8,000 meticals per month.

This is her first loan from Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner) and the fourth in her life. The first three loans were with BIM, the International Bank of Mozambique. The first loan was for 20,000 meticals, the second for 25,000 meticals, and the third for 50,000 meticals. They were used to buy a vehicle, repair her house, and legalize (secure the title to) her plot of land. One of the problems that made her switch to Hluvuku is that the large banks are not flexible with repayments, which prolongs the debt and makes the interest payments unmanageable.

Her dream is to have a bird house and raise chickens, with a goal of making 1,000 meticals per month.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer.

Maria de Lurdes J. tem 49 anos de idade e natural da Província de Inhambane ao sul de Moçambique, divorciada e mae de 2 filhos com idades entre 30 e 28 anos respectivamente. Sustenta a sua mae e uma neta enviando dinheiro periodicamente.

Estudou até 9ªclasse e parou quando se casou. Desde a sua infancia viveu com os seus proprios pais até 1976 quando concluiu a 7ªclasse e por falta de classe posteriores viu se obrigada a transferir se da provincia de origem a cidade de maputo onde veio a continuar com os estudos na casa do seu irmão e dois anos depois conheceu o homem que veio a ser o seu marido e pai dos seus dois filhos. Vive numa casa própria.

Maria é funcionaria do ministerio da saude e trabalha num centro de saude na cidade de maputo desde 1999, tem um horário das 7:30 às 15:30h com um salário mensal de 8000,00mt.

Este é seu primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku e Quarto na Vida os tres primeiros foi no BIM banco internacional de Moçambique nos seguintes valores primeiro 20000,00mt, segundo 25000,00mt e o terceiro foi de 50000,00mt tendo aplicados na compra de Viatura, reabilitação da Casa e legalização do terreno. Um dos problemas que faz com que ela mude para HLUVUKU, os grandes bancos nao sao flexiveis para reembolsos o que torna a divida mais prolongada e os juros tornam se insuportaveis.

Constitui seu sonho ter um aviario e criar frangos cuja meta é de 1.000 por mes.

loans.use: To buy material to build her family’s house

loans.name: Faithful Group

texts.en:
These group members are Ramatu Kamara and Aminata B.. They named their group Faithful. They are requesting a loan of Le 1,200,000. The former sells ground-nuts and palm-oil during the raining season (between April and September) and "gara lappers" (locally dyed clothes) in the dry season (October to March). Like the former, the latter also sells garas during the dry season, and market food and fire woods during the raining season. This is because, during the rains, edible products sell more than clothes.

Ramatu is the leader of the group. She is now 33 and is single with one child. She was born in Makeni and has been in this business for over 3 years now. Ramatu's previous loan helped her a lot. She was able to pay her child's fee for the National Primary School Exams. She was able to solve most of her numerous problems out of the proceeds she gets from the business. With a new loan, she expects to buy a total of 10 bags of ground nuts and 12 "batters" (5 gallons make a batter) of palm-oil. Previously, she was trading with only 5 bags of rice and 6 batters of palm-oil.

loans.use: Expand on their businesses.

loans.name: Lourenço

texts.pt:
Lourenço (Lorenzo) B. is 35 years old, a native of the Maputo Province, married, and the father of two children. His children are 10 and 12 years old, and both are in school. He supports only his children. Sometimes he helps his parents by sending them some money.

Lourenço studied through tenth grade and stopped when he got engaged to be married, which obligated him to look for work to support his family. He has never moved from the city, and he moved out of his parents’ house in 1996, the year he got married.

Lourenço worked as an electrician at a company in that industry for eight years, working from 7am to 5pm. He learned to do this kind of work at industrial school and has ten years of experience. His monthly salary is 5,500 meticals, and he manages to save some. He lives in his own house.

With a loan of 15,000 meticals, he intends to legalize (pay the fees and get the rights to) a plot of land where he will construct another house in order to increase the family’s assets.

This is Lourenço’s first loan with Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner), and he has never had another loan with any other bank. His dream or future project is to build a suitable house and live suitably with his family.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer.

Lourenço B. tem 35 anos de idade é natural da Província do Maputo, casado e pai de 2 filhos com idade entre 12 e 10 respectivamente e ambos estudantes. Apenas sustenta os seus filhos. As vezes ajuda os seus pais enviando algum valor monetário.

Lourenço estudou até décima classe e parou de estudar por ter contraído matrimonio, situação que lhe obrigou a procurar emprego para sustentar a sua família. Nunca mudou de cidade e deixou de viver na casa dos pais em 1996 ano quando contraiu o matrimonio.

Lourenço trabalha como electricista numa das empresas vocacionadas neste ramo a 8 anos, tem um horário das 7 às 17horas. Aprendeu a fazer este trabalho na escola industrial e tem uma experiência de 10 anos. Tem um salário mensal de 5.500,00MT e consegue poupar algum. Vive numa casa própria.

Com emprestimode 15.000,00MT pretende legalizar um terreno onde pretende construir outra casa para aumentar os activos da familia.

Este é o primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku e nunca teve nenhum empréstimo noutros bancos. Tem como sonho ou projectos para futuro construir uma casa condigna e viver condignamente com a sua família.

loans.use: To buy material to build his family’s house

loans.name: Rosmery Jeanet

texts.es:
Rosmery is a young mother who works arduously in agriculture, thus helping her husband with the household expenses so that they can have greater possibilities to improve their quality of life and provide their 6-year-old daughter with the necessities of life. She works at home until very late, packing the herbs that will later be sold. It is very heavy work because she has to further cut the plants, but this does not daunt her desire to keep working. Furthermore, she would like to expand her crop fields, but for in order to do so, she needs a loan of 1,000 Peruvian soles. She hopes that you will be able to help her increase her crops so that she can continue to support her partner with the family expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosmery, es una joven madre que trabaja arduamente en la agricultura, así ayuda a su esposo con los gastos dentro de su hogar, para tener mayores posibilidades de mejorar su calidad de vida y brindarle lo necesario a su pequeña hija de tan solo 6 años.Ella trabaja hasta muy tarde en su casa empaquetando las hierbas que después serían vendidas, este trabajo es muy pesado y cortar la hierba aún más, pero eso no amilana sus deseos de seguir trabajando.De igual manera, quiere incrementar sus terrenos de cultivos y para ello solicita un préstamo de 1000 soles, espera que usted pueda ayudarla a ampliar sus cultivos y así seguir apoyando a su pareja en los gastos familiares.

loans.use: Capital for crop fields

loans.name: Leila Mariza

texts.pt:
Leila Mariza E. is 45 years old, a native of the Maputo province, married, and the mother of four children between the ages of 6 and 24. The oldest works in South Africa, a neighboring country to Mozambique. Leila supports only her other three children.

Leila studied through seventh grade, then stopped because she lost her mother very early and therefore had to look for work to support her siblings. She has never moved from the city and started working when she was 17 years old, after she lost her mother. She had her first child when she was 21 and with her first husband, with whom she separated. Later she met the man with whom she has been living and continues to live today. She lives in her own house, which is still under construction.

Leila has been an employee at the Military Hospital in Maputo for 20 years, with a monthly salary of 2,850 meticals. She does not manage to save anything. This is her third loan with Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner). The first and second loans were for 10,000 meticals each. The first was used to buy consumer goods. The second and third loans were to buy construction material. Her dream is to give her children a good education.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer.

Leila Mariza E. tem 45 anos de idade e natural da província do Maputo, casada maritalmente e mae de 4 filhos com idade entre 24 - 6 anos. O mais velho já trabalha na RSA pais vizinho de Moçambique. Apenas sustenta os seus 3 filhos.

Leila Estudou até sétima classe, parou de estudar por ter perdido a sua mae muito cedo, onde cedo teve que procurar emprego para sustentar os seus irmãos. Nunca mudou de cidade e começou a trabalhar quando tinha 17 anos de idade, depois de perder a mãe. Teve o primeiro filho aos 21 anos com primeiro marido e separou. Mais tarde conheceu o actual homem com quem vive até hoje. Vive numa casa própria a qual ainda está em construção.

Leila é funcionária do Hospital Militar em Maputo à 20 anos, tem um salário mensal de 2850,00mt. Não consegue poupar nada. Este é o terceiro empréstimo na Hluvuku. O primeiro foi de 10000,00mt e usou para compra de bens de consumo e o segundo foi de 10000,00mt. O segundo e o terceiro destinara para compra de material de construção. Tem como sonho fazer com que os filhos tenha uma boa educação.

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Simón

texts.es:
L. works arduously in his bakery, which has been in business for over 15 years, generating his daily income. With the profits, he was able to provide an education for his children, who are now adults. He sells bread wholesale in his bakery, working nights alongside his children so that the bread can be ready to be distributed in the early hours of the morning. L. would like to improve his bakery and install a display case so that he can open to the general public full-time, and sell not only bread, but also other products in order to boost profits. For this reason, he is requesting a loan so that he can purchase everything needed for redecorating his bakery and prepare for his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

L. trabaja arduamente en su panadería, que por más de quince años lleva funcionando y le ha generado un ingreso diario, con este pudo educar a sus hijos, quienes ya son adultos.Su panadería es sólo para reparto de panes al por mayor, L. trabaja en la noche junto a sus hijos mayores para tener listo los panes en la madrugada y puedan ser distribuidos.L. desea mejorar el ambiente de su panadería e instalar un mostrador para vender al público en general, a tiempo completo, no solo panes, sino también otros productos para mejorar sus ingresos.Por ello que solicita un préstamo para que pueda adquirir lo necesario para la ambientación de su panadería y prepararse para la llegada de sus clientes.

loans.use: Improve the lay out of the bakery and install a display case to serve the public

loans.name: Wilmer Raydo

texts.es:
Wilmer is a young man who has the opportunity to work as a farmer. He continues to work arduously on his coffee plant fields, where he works with much joy and optimism. He has the ambition to one day become the best coffee merchant in his area. Not only that, but he would also like to have the opportunity to export his crops to other countries. This dream propels him to keep improving his crops on a daily basis. Nevertheless, at this time he needs financial support in order to expand his coffee plant fields. For this reason, he is requesting a loan, money that he hopes you will be able to help him obtain, thus improving both crop production and his income.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Wilmer es un joven que tiene la oportunidad de desarrollarse como agricultor, no deja de trabajar arduamente sus cultivos de café, donde trabaja con mucha alegría y optimismo.Tiene la ambición de ser algún día el mejor comerciante de café de su zona, y no tan solo eso, sino también tener la oportunidad de exportar a otros países, este sueño lo impulsa a que día a día siga mejorando sus productos.Sin embargo, en estos momentos necesita un apoyo económico para crecer y ampliar sus cultivos de café, por ello solicita un préstamo, dinero que espera usted pueda ayudar a conseguir, y así mejorar su producción y sus ingresos económicos.

loans.use: Increase coffee plants and improve their quality

loans.name: Jorge Alberto

texts.pt:
Jorge Alberto Z. was born in the Bongane district of the Xai-xai Province of Gaza, in the south of Mozambique. He is 32 years old and married with a 2-year-old child. He also takes care of his mother and a nephew orphaned by his father.

Jorge completed basic study at the 7 de Setembro (September 7, Mozambique’s Independence Day in 1974) school in Xai-xai. Because a shortage of vacancies in middle school prevented him from continuing his studies, he had to apply early for a spot as a basic level teacher in 1997. The following year he entered the Matola Primary school for teaching, where he finished in 1999. In 2000 he applied for a teaching position in Catembe and because he had the will to continue his studies he applied to the higher education institute Maria Mãe Africa (Mother Maria Africa), earned his Bachelor’s degree, and continues to pursue a License in Educational Sciences.

Jorge has been employed as a teacher since 2000 and works from 7:00 to 11:45am as a professor, trained by the courses he took. His monthly earnings are 5,246 meticals, and he lives in government housing. This is his sixth loan with Hluvuku (Kiva’s Field Partner) and is for legalization of a plot of land. The other loans were used to buy oxen. In the future he intends to increase his stock of animals with the purchase of goats and to build his own house.

Translated from Portuguese by April Newman, Kiva Volunteer.

Jorge Alberto Z. nasceu em Bongane distrito de Xai-xai Provincia de Gaza ao sul de Moçambique, tem 32 anos de idade é casado maritalmente. Tem um filho de 2 anos de idade e sustenta para alem da mae um sobrinho orfão do pai.

Fez o ensino Básico na escola 7 de Setembro em Xai-xai e por que havia dificuldades para continuar por falta de vagas no ensino médio teve que concorrer desde cedo para uma vaga como docente de ensino Básico em 1997 e no ano seguinte ingressou no instituto de magistério Primário da Matola onde concluiu em 1999 e em 200 concorreu para docente na Catembe e porque tinha vontade de continuar os estudos concorreu para o instituto superior maria mãe Africa, fez o Bacharelato e continua a estudar para concluir a Licenciatura em ciencias de educação.

É docente efectivo desde 2000 e entra das 7:00 às 11:45 a experiencia como professor deriva dos cursos que frequentou. Tem um rendimento mensal de 5.246,00MT e vive na casa do estado. Este é o sexto empréstimo na Hluvuku e é para legalização do terreno. Os outros emprestimos destinou para compra de gado Bovino. No futuro pretende ampliar sua criação na compra de gado caprino e construir sua própria casa.

loans.use: To pay taxes and expenses for land acquisition

loans.name: Justina

texts.es:
Justina is a young mother who cultivates citrus. However, citrus season is coming to an end, so she needs to prepare to grow bananas, which she would like to sell in the nearby cities, especially in commercial areas. Her job is very laborious, so she must work hard everyday in order to yield a large amount of crops that will allow for greater profits. Justina is quite worried because the profits that she will earn will not be sufficient to increase her crops. As a result, she is requesting a loan that she will invest in the purchase of citrus plants that she will cultivate before the end of the season.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Justina es una joven madre que trabaja cultivando frutos cítricos, de los cuales la temporada de producción está llegando a su fin, entonces tiene que prepararse para la producción de de platanales, los que quiere llevar a vender a las ciudades aledañas, en especial donde hay mayor flujo comercial. Su trabajo es muy cansado, día tras día debe esforzarse para obtener gran cantidad de productos que le permitan conseguir mayores ingresos.Justina está muy preocupada porque el dinero que obtendrá como ganancia no le será suficiente para ampliar sus cultivos, por ello solicita un préstamo, dinero que invertirá en la compra de plantas de cítricos que desea cultivar antes de que termine la temporada.

loans.use: Purchase citrus plants to increase production

loans.name: Jacinto

texts.pt:
Jacinto H. is 39 years old and was born in the province of Zambeze in the center of Mozambique. He is married and the father of 2 children who are 12 and 8 years old respectively. Both go to school. Beyond his children he supports his mother-in-law and a nephew who live with them.

Jacinto studied until the basic level of agriculture. He stopped when his country called upon him to join the Armed Forced of Mozambique. He began very young living away from his parents in the house of his uncle so he could go to school because the area where his parents lived did not have a school.

He moved from the province of Zambezia in 1987 when he entered the armed forces, and in 1990 he got married. Now he lives in his own home. Jacinto has worked for the Ministry of Defense since 1987 and works from 7:30am to 3:30pm with a monthly salary of 9,650MT. He is able to save a little money at the end of every month.

This is his fourth loan in his life, one of which was from the International Bank of Mozambique, 2 were from Hluvuku, and all were used to purchase construction materials. He has a dream to purchase a vehicle, and to realize his dream he counts on loans.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Jacinto H. tem 39 anos de idade e nasceu na província da Zambeze no Centro de Moçambique, casado maritalmente e pai de 2 filhos com 12 e 8 anos de idade respectivamente. Ambos vao a escola. Para alem dos seus filhos sustenta uma sogra e um sobrinho que vive com eles. Jacinto H. estudou até Nível Básico em agricultura. Parou de estudar quando a pátria chamou por ele para ingressar nas FADM – Forcas Armadas de Mocambique . Muito cedo começou a viver fora dos seus pais em casa do tio para poder estudar dado que lá no campo que viviam os seus pais não tinha escola. E mudou se da provincia da Zambezia em 1987 quando ingressou nas FADM e em 1990 se casou. Neste momento vive numa casa própria. Jacinto trabalha no ministério da defesa desde 1987 e tem um horário das 7:30 às 15:30h com um salário mensal de 9.650,00mt e consegue poupar algum no fim de cada mes. Este é o quarto empréstimo na vida dos quais um foi na BIM banco internacional de Moçambique e os dois foram na Hluvuku e todos foram aplicados na compra de material de construção. Tem como sonho comprar uma viatura e para concretizar seu sonho conta com os empréstimos.

loans.use: to buy construction materials

loans.name: Victoria Francisca

texts.es:
“Bodeguita Santa Celodonia” is Francisca’s general store. More than six years ago, she decided to set up a space in her home to sell groceries, thus meeting the demands of her customers, who are always satisfied with the cordiality and good service that they receive daily. Francisca started selling few goods in the inconvenient space, but with the passing of time and with her family’s support, they were able to refurbish their home and increase product variety. She is fortunate to currently have numerous customers. Francisca and her family plan on expanding their general store and increasing its stock. She is sure that with your support, her plans will crystallize.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Bodeguita “Santa Celodonia” es la tienda de Francisca, quien desde hace más de 6 años decidió adecuar un espacio de su casa para la venta de abarrotes, complaciendo así la solicitud de sus clientes quienes quedan satisfechos por la cordialidad y buena atención que diariamente reciben. Francisca inició vendiendo poca mercadería bajo la incomodidad del espacio, pero con el transcurso del tiempo y el apoyo incondicional de su esposo e hijos lograron refaccionar su vivienda y aumentaron la variedad de sus productos, actualmente tiene la dicha de contar con innumerables clientes. Francisca y su familia tienen en mente ampliar y aumentar el stock de su mercadería, está segura que con su apoyo se cristalizará ese proyecto.

loans.use: Expand and restock general store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Incarnación

texts.es:
Incarnación is a woman with a humble heart. Ever since she started her family, she has had a very close relationship with her husband and children, but due to financial necessity, her husband had to leave in search of better job opportunities so that his family may enjoy a better quality of life. Meanwhile, Incarnación works hard in all her duties. For her, neither exhaustion nor sickness exists as long as she can work to cover the family expenses. She sells vegetables as a street vendor, works in a brick factory, and provides laundry services for her neighbors, who know that she is an active, industrious, exemplary mother. This selfless woman’s wish is to have greater capital for her business. She is sure that with this loan, she will be able to increase her earnings and provide for her adorable children.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Incarnación es una mujer humilde de corazón, desde que formó su hogar estuvo muy unida a su esposo e hijos, pero por necesidad su esposo tuvo que separarse e ir en busca de mejores oportunidades de trabajo con el fin de que su familia goce de una mejor calidad de vida.En tanto, Incarnación se esfuerza en sus labores, para ella no existe cansancio ni enfermedad con tal de trabajar y cubrir las necesidades de sus hijos, se dedica a la venta de verduras en forma ambulatoria, así mismo es obrera en una fabrica de ladrillo y eventualmente lava ropa de sus vecinos, quienes la reconocen como una madre ejemplar, activa y trabajadoraEl deseo de esta abnegada mujer es contar con mayor capital de inversión en su negocio, está segura que con estas proyecciones podrá mejorara sus ingresos y mantener sin privaciones a sus adorables hijos.

loans.use: Invest in vegetable business

loans.name: Florinda Gabriel

texts.pt:
Florinda Gabriel M. is 40 years old and a native of Homoine province of Inhambane in the south of Mozambique. She is married and is the mother of one son who is 20 years old and is a student. She supports her son and lives in her own home.

Florinda went to school until the 9th grade and is currently attending 10th grade. She had stopped due to the poor conditions of her ancestors. She moved with her parents from the province of Inhambane when she was a child, but she doesn't know the reasons.

Florinda works at the Military Hospital of Maputo as a health assistant. She earns a monthly salary of 2,820MT but is unable to save any money. This is her third loan with Hluvuku. The first was for 7,000MT, the second was for 8,000MT, and the third will be for 12,000MT. All the loans were used to purchase construction materials that she is doing in phases. She learned of Hluvuku through colleagues that are clients. She projects in the future purchasing a vehicle for which she will need additional loans.

Translated from Portuguese by jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Florinda Gabriel M. tem 40 anos de idade, natural de Homoine província de Inhambane ao sul de Moçambique. Casada maritalmente e mae de 1 filho com 20 anos de idade e é estudante. Apenas sustenta o seu filho. Vive numa casa propria. Florinda estudou até 9ªclasse e agora está frequentar a 10ªclasse, tinha parado devido a falta de condições por parte dos seus progenitores. Mudou da provincia de Inhambane quando criança junto com os pais e não soube as razões. Florinda é funcionária do Hospital Militar de Maputo como auxiliar da saúde, tem um salário mensal de 2.820,00mt e não faz nenhuma poupança. Este é o terceiro empréstimo na Hluvuku. O primeiro foi de 7.000,00MT; o segundo foi de 8000,00MT e o terceiro que será de 12.000,00mt. Todos destinam para compra de material de construção estando a construir por fases. Conheceu a hluvuku atraves dos colegas que sao clientes. Tem como projecto para futuro comprar uma viatura, para tal conta com futuros empréstimo.

loans.use: to buy construction materials

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.es:
Marcelina started her own business because she wanted to have the extra income that would allow her to help out with the household expenses. She wanted to help her husband so that their children, who at that time were minors, would not lack anything. Sixteen years ago, she started her piñata business, initially only making them for her family members. Little by little, more people got word of her skills, and now she sells her piñatas to the owners of candy stores and banquet halls.

She needs a loan of $900.00 USD, which she will repay in 6 months, in order to purchase more materials so that she can finish some piñatas that have been ordered. With your help, she will make her business grow.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Marcelina inició el negocio por que queria tener un ingreso que le permitiera apoyar con los gastos de la casa y ayudar a su esposo para que a sus hijos que en aquel entonces eran menores no les faltara nada. Comenzó su negocio hace 16 años con la venta de piñatas, haciendolas para familiares y así poco a poco mas personas la conocieron de que hacia piñatas y actualmente le vende a algunas dulcerías y salones de fiestas.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $900 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar material de trabajo, y poder terminar algunas piñatas que ya tiene vendidas. Con tu apoyo ella hara crecer su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase materials to make piñatas

loans.name: Zonia Glicelda

texts.es:
Over the years, Glicelda has been perfecting the technique and design of her knitwork. She started knitting by hand, but time and experience have turned her into a skilled and talented woman in this art. Her reasons for working with so much dedication are her 4 underage children, who need care, nourishment, and an education. Meanwhile, her husband, Máximo, does seasonal work as a master bricklayer, which affects their modest household finances. For this reason, Glicelda decided to increase her clothing production. She is requesting this current loan in order to obtain materials (wool) and strengthen her knitting workshop.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Glicelda ha lo largo de los años fue perfeccionando la técnica y diseño de sus tejidos, se inició tejiendo manualmente, pero el tiempo y la experiencia la convirtieron en una mujer con gran habilidad y talento para este arte, el motivo por el que se desempeña con mucha constancia son sus 4 menores hijos, quienes requieren de cuidado, alimentación y educación. En tanto, su esposo Máximo, se desempeña en trabajos eventuales como maestro albañil, en muchas oportunidades la económica de su modesto hogar se vio afectada, por ello, Glicelda decidió aumentar el volumen de producción de sus prendas. Solicita el presente préstamo para adquirir materia prima (lana) y fortalecer su taller de tejidos.

loans.use: Purchase a variety of wool for her knitwork

loans.name: Ronald Melanio

texts.es:
The art of knitting is one of Ronald’s qualities. Ever since he was a boy, he has had ties to this line of work due to the fact that his parents were among the best artisans in the area. Ronald makes lovely chullos (Peruvian hats), gloves, and chalinas (Peruvian scarves), which are greatly treasured by his customers, who satisfactorily acquire his beautiful knitwork. Ronald’s dream is to have a knitting factory in which he can offer employment to talented youth in this same discipline. This young man is requesting a loan that will be invested in obtaining a variety of wool. He promises to repay this loan in a punctual and responsible manner.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

El arte de tejer, es una de las cualidades de Ronald, desde muy niño estuvo ligado a esta labor, debido a que sus padres fueron uno de los mejores artesanos de su localidad.Ronald elabora diariamente hermosos chullos, guantes y chalinas, prendas que son muy bien valoradas por sus clientes, quienes satisfechos y admirados, adquieren sus hermosos tejidos. El sueño de Ronald es tener un taller de tejidos, lugar donde pueda brindar trabajo a otros jóvenes talentosos en este mismo arte. Este joven solicita este préstamo, que será invertido en adquirir variedad de lana, prometiendo ser puntual y responsable en el reembolso de dicho préstamo.

loans.use: Purchase wool for knitwork

loans.name: Fernando António

texts.pt:
Fernando António B. is 48 years old and a native of the province of Gaza in the south of Mozambique. He is married and the father of 5 children with ages 28, 26, twins at 19 and the youngest is 9 years old. One is at home, 3 are still students, and one works for the RSA.

Fernando went to school until the 9th grade. He stopped for his obligatory military service that caused him to travel a lot. He lived with his parents until he was 16 when he moved to Maputo after finishing the 4th grade. He stayed in Maputo through the 9th grade and later enrolled in the S.M.O.
