Now days, after a year of effort, the small store has increased so much on products as well as clients that now is selling meat, clothes and toys.

She will use the credit to acquire sugar, milk, beverages, flour, rice, pasta, bread, among others in large quantities and get more profit, which will help on the educational growth of her kids.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

Blanca tiene 43 años de edad, está casada con el Sr. Eugenio Colmán, tienen 4 hijos, todos ellos estudian aún en la escuela primaria de la ciudad.

Blanca trabaja como docente con una antigüedad de 19 años y su marido trabajaba en ventas varias hasta hace un año atrás. Blanca debido a la necesidad de mejorar la calidad de vida de sus hijos, y gracias al sacrificio de tantos años de labores educativas y con el apoyo incondicional de su esposo decidieron abrir una pequeña despensa la cual es atendida por su esposo.

Hoy en día, y después de un año de mucho esfuerzo, la pequeña despensa ha aumentado tanto en diversidad de mercaderías como también en cantidad de clientes; tanto fue su crecimiento que están vendiendo carnes, artículos de mercería, bazar y juguetería.

Pretende utilizar el crédito para adquirir mercaderías azúcar, lácteos, bebidas en general, harina, arroz, fideo, panificados, entre otros, en gran cantidad y así poder obtener un poco más de ganancias, las cuales les ayudarán en el crecimiento educativo de sus hijos.

loans.use: To buy products like sugar, milk, beverages, flour, rice, pasta, bread, among others / Compra de mercaderías como azúcar, lácteos, bebidas en general, harina, arroz, fideo, panificados, entre otros.

loans.name: La Paz De Dios (The Peace Of God) Group 1

texts.en:
Candida F. lives in a poor community outside of El Seybo with her husband and her youngest child (age 15). Her two middle children live in her same community, but in their own homes. Her oldest lives in the beach city of Bavaro. She has four grandchildren. Candida has a small “colmado,” or mini-market, where she sells various food products including chicken and vegetables. She buys packaged food from a warehouse in El Seybo, the chicken from a chicken vender and the vegetables from the market. She then transports all her purchases home to her community where she sells them to her neighbors. The hardest part of her business is having to transport so much from El Seybo to her community, using only a motorcycle.

Candida has successfully repaid five loans to Esperanza International and is now requesting her sixth loan. With this loan of $2000, she hopes to continue growing her small colmado and support her youngest in school. In the photo, she is at a meeting with the other four members of her group so that her loan officer can prepare to give them another loan.

Note: This is a group loan for five people. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To grow her mini-market by buying more inventory

loans.name: La Paz De Dios (The Peace Of God) Group 5

texts.en:
Belkis H. lives in a rural, poor area outside of El Seybo with her husband. She has four children, but they are all grown now and living in neighboring cities. Five years ago, her husband was involved in a street fight and was badly injured. He can’t walk or work anymore. Through her grocery business, Belkis has been able to support him, care for their needs, buy medicine for him, and even pay for an expensive surgery.

When she received her first loan from Esperanza International, Belkis had a small “colmado,” or mini-grocery store. With the three loans, she has expanded the colmado to about five times its original size and is now selling more products like shoes, jewelry, dishes, soaps and shampoo. With her fourth loan, she plans to fill the empty shelves of the larger colmado with more products like cooking oil, vinegar, etc. Hopefully within the next year, she plans to convert her colmado into an “almacen” or warehouse where she can supply goods in bulk to other colmados in the area. She is currently working on supplying her house and colmado with electricity so that she can use the freezer she recently bought. Eventually, she would like to buy a television, but business growth is more important right now.

In the photo, Belkis and the other four members of her group are meeting with their loan officer to prepare to receive their next loan. This is a group loan for five people. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To grow her small grocery store and eventually expand into a warehouse

loans.name: Lea Esmeralda

texts.es:
Esmeralda has been a seamstress for 8 years, and she lives with her parents in Lourdes-Colon. Bit by bit she has come to know the people around her who specialize in making dresses and she says that they currently export their dresses. Her dream is to start a formal business employing staff in order to expand more. She thinks it is important to have more room to serve her clients so she would like to build a concrete platform for a second floor so that her family would be more comfortable and so that she can serve her clients in a more independent space, and this is why she wants a loan. It is important to mention that Esmeralda has had various loans which she has paid back on time.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

La Srta. Esmeralda se dedica al trabajo de costurera desde hace 8 años, vive con sus padres en Lourdes-Colón. Poco a poco se ha dado a conocer con la gente de los alrededores, se ha ido especializando en la confección de vestidos, comenta que hoy en día, tiene clientes que exportan sus vestidos. Su visión es la de montar un negocio más formal donde pueda tener operarias, para expandirse más. Cree que es importante tener más espacio para atender a los clientes, así es que tiene planeado hacer un pequeño plafón de concreto para una segunda planta para que pueda estar más cómoda su familia y poder atender en un espacio más independiente a los clientes, razón por la cual esta solicitando un préstamo. Es importante mencionar que Esmeralda a tenido varios prestamos los cuales ha pagado con puntualidad.

loans.use: To build a platform for the second floor of the house/Para construcción de Plafon para 2do. nivel en vivienda

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: El Manantial Group

texts.es:
In the city of Yaguaron, 15Km. away from the Paraguari office, a group of women who wanted to start entrepreneurial activities got together and increased their working capital in order to improve their quality of life and their families, so they contacted us to learn about the program, they accepted the opportunity offered by this institution.

The committee’s name is El Manantial, they are currently on the first cycle, with great qualifications, formed by 16 entrepreneurial and active women. These women have invested each on their respective activities, they are learning and valuing the importance of forming a committee because of the opportunities that they get , to grow as people and improve their quality of life for their families.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

En la ciudad de Yaguarón, distante a 15 Km. De la Oficina de Paraguarí, se reunieron unas mujeres con ganas de emprender actividades productivas y otras para aumentar su capital de trabajo con el fin de mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia, de ahí que se pusieron en contacto con nosotros para interiorizarse sobre el programa, quienes aceptaron por la oportunidad que se les está ofreciendo ya que ninguna otra institución lo ha hecho.

El comité lleva por nombre El Manantial, quienes actualmente se encuentran en el primer ciclo, con calificación excelente, integrada por 16 emprendedoras y activas mujeres. Estas mujeres han invertido cada una en sus respectivas actividades, quienes están aprendiendo y valorando la importancia de conformar un comité por las oportunidades que se les presenta para crecer como persona y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.

loans.use: Your loan will be invested on each one of their activities, like buying meat, beverages, bread, oil, pasta, rice, flour, milk, clothes, bed sheets, medicine, fruits and vegetables and groceries items, etc. / Sus créditos han invertido cada una en sus respectivas actividades, como son la compra de carne, bebidas, panificados, aceite, fideo, arroz, harina, lácteos, zapillas, cacerolas, ropas, sábanas, remedios, frutas y verduras en general, accesorios de mercería, ect.

loans.name: Elida

texts.es:
Mrs. Elida is 35 years old, she is married to Isidro Flecha (38 years old), who works in the Paraguari Transport company and helps her to cover the daily expenses.

They have two daughters, one is currently on her second year of Law school and the other one is in High School thanks to the sacrifice of their parents. She started her business in her own home three years ago. She learnt basic hairdressing skills working as a hairdresser assistant. Due to her initiative and her desire to get ahead she got into a Hairdressing institute in the capital so that she could improve her technique and skills.

She is requesting a loan so that she can buy a backwash unit to diversify her services and provide more comfort to her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Elida tiene 35 años, está casada con el Sr. Isidro Flecha, de 38 años, quien trabaja en la Empresa de Transporte Paraguarí; quien le ayuda en gran parte a cubrir los gastos del hogar.

Tienen dos hijas, una actualmente esta cursando el segundo año de Derecho y la otra hija cursa la secundaria mediante el sacrificio de sus padres.

Su negocio se inició hace 3 años en su domicilio. Adquirió los conocimientos básicos siendo ayudante en una peluqueria. Pero por iniciativa y por el deseo de superacion ingresó a un instituto superior de peluqueria en la capital, para el perfeccionamiento de las técnicas y métodos.

Necesita el crédito para la compra de una silla de lavado para la diversificación de sus servicios, y mayor comodidad de sus clientes.

loans.use: To buy a swivel chair (backwash unit)

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
In the city of Yaguaron, 15Km away from the Paraguari office, a group of women who wanted to start entrepreneurial activities got together and increased their working capital in order to improve their quality of life and their families, so they contacted us to learn about the program, they accepted the opportunity offered by this institution as no other does.

The committee’s name is El Nueva Esperanza, they are currently on the first cycle, with great qualifications, formed by 16 entrepreneurial and active women. These women are women of very few resources who are very grateful to Fundacion Paraguaya for the opportunity given, to increase their working capital, giving her the possibility to increase their income and therefore improve their quality of life and their families.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

En la ciudad de Yaguarón, distante a 15 Km. de la Oficina de Paraguarí, se reunieron unas mujeres con ganas de emprender actividades productivas y otras para aumentar su capital de trabajo con el fin de mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia, de ahí que se pusieron en contacto con nosotros para interiorizarse sobre el programa, quienes aceptaron por la oportunidad que se les está ofreciendo ya que ninguna otra institución lo ha hecho.

El comité lleva por nombre Nueva Esperanza, quienes actualmente se encuentran en el primer ciclo, con calificación excelente, integrada por 16 emprendedoras y activas mujeres.

Estas mujeres son personas de muy escasos recursos quienes están muy agradecidas a la Fundación Paraguaya por la oportunidad que se le está dando, para aumentar su capital de trabajo, dandole la posibilidad de mejorar sus ingresos y por ende su calidad de vida y las de sus familias.

loans.use: Your loan will be invested on each one of their activities, like buying meat, beverages, bread, oil, pasta, rice, flour, milk, clothes, bed sheets, medicine, fruits and vegetables and groceries items, etc. / Sus créditos han invertido cada una en sus respectivas actividades, como son la compra de golosinas como chicle, caramelo, galletitas, carne, bebidas, panificados, aceite, fideo, arroz, harina, lácteos, zapillas, lencería, ropas, sábanas, remedios, frutas y verduras en general, hilo, telas, ect.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Mrs. Rosa is 38 years old, single and lives with her parents, she has an eight year old son in school.

Since she was very young she went to Argentina where she worked for 10 years, when she returned to her country she started her business with her savings and in order to stay with her parents to take care of them.

Her dream is that her son finishes his studies and be a professional one day, Rosa works 15 hours each day to help her parents and son, her business is located 10Km from the city in front of a school and next to a soccer field, thanks to her good attention her sales have increased considerably.

She needs the loan to buy a freezer.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Rosa tiene 38 años, es soltera, vive con sus padres, tiene un hijo de ocho años quien está en la escuela.

Desde muy joven fue a la Argentina donde trabajó durante diez años, al regresar al país utilizó su ahorro para empezar su negocio y poder quedarse con sus padres para cuidarlos.

Su sueño es que su hijo culmine sus estudios y asi ser profesional, Rosa trabaja 15 horas diarias para ayudar a sus padres e hijo, su negocio está ubicado a 10km de la ciudad frente a una escuela y al costado de una cancha de fútbol, gracias a su buena atención ha aumentado considerablente sus ventas.

Necesita el crédito para la compra de una congeladora.

loans.use: To buy a freezer / Compra de una congeladora

loans.name: Valentín

texts.es:
Mr. Valentin is 63 years old; he is married with Nimia Meza who is 61 years old who works sewing, to help the family’s finances.

They have 3 children, all grown now, two of them are professionals and one is finishing college, all live on their own houses.

Valentin started as his father’s tire repair shop helper, where he learned the job, for the last 40 years he works by himself, currently is working with him a nephew that he pays to, while teaches him the job.

His tire repair place is located near an international road and a service station. Today the quantity of vehicles and motorcycles in the zone have increased so he has more work, and is very well known because of the quality of his services, so his repair shop is very well visited.

He needs the credit to buy an air compressor.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Valentin tiene 63 años, está casado con Nimia Meza de 61 años quien se dedica a la costura, ayudando económicamente para el sustento familiar.

Tienen 3 hijos, todos mayores de edad, dos de los cuales ya son profesionales y uno está en la facultad, viven en casa propia.

Valentin comenzó como ayudante de su padre de quien aprendió el oficio, desde hace 40 años trabaja por cuenta propia, actualmente está trabajando con él un sobrino a quien le remunera y a la vez le enseña el oficio.

Su gomería esta bien ubicado al costado de una ruta internacional y de una estación de servicio. Hoy día ha aumentado la cantidad de vehículos y motos en la zona que hace que tenga mucho trabajo, además es muy conocido por la calidad de sus servicios, motivo por el cual es muy concurrida su gomería.

Necesita el crédito para la compra de una compresora.

loans.use: Air Compressor / Aire compresora

loans.name: Cesar Antonio

texts.es:
Cesar Antonio B. is from the Mongelos neighborhood of the city of San Estanislao. He is married to Lilliana Mabel Rojas and they have a daughter.

Cesar works as a street vendor in various parts of the city selling sewing supplies and costume jewelry to a well developed client base. The works earns him a good income. He's been working in this business since 2002.

Cesar would like to buy more merchandise for his inventory, since he has a lot of orders from his clients. With the additional merchandise he will generate better earnings and begin to improve his family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Cesar Antonio B. es de la ciudad de San Estanislao del Barrio Mongelos, està casado con la Señora Liliana Mabel Rojas, y tienen 1 hijo.

Se dedica como vendedor ambulante de Articulos de Mercerias y Viyouterias, con clientela formada, por varias zonas , lo que le genera buenos ingresos. Empesò con esta actividad desde el año 2002.

El Sr. Cesar B. quiere comprar màs mercaderìas para la venta, ya que tiene muchos pedidos de clientes, lo que le generarà màs ingresos y tambièn va mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Fermin

texts.es:
Fermin P. is from the city of San Estanislao. He is 52 years old and married to Graciela Aguilar, who is 35. They have 2 school age children.

Fermin has a Santana brand car which he uses as a taxi. He has 2 stops, one at the municipal market and the other at the bus terminal. He has worked in the taxi business since 2003, and supports his family with his taxi.

He wants to build a room designed to use for commercial purposes in his home, in order to start a second business his wife can run from home, as way to increase the family's earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Fermin P., es de la ciudad de San Estanislao, tiene 52 años de edad, esta casado con la señora Graciela Aguilar de 35 años de edad, actualmente tienen 2 hijos, y todos en edad escolar.

Tiene un Automóvil de la marca Santana, en el cual trabaja como Taxi de Pasajeros, Tiene 2 paradas, uno en el mercado municipal y otro en la Terminal de Omnibus. Trabaja en esta actividad desde el año 2003, y con este trabajo, està manteniendo a su familia

Quiere construir un salon comercial en su casa, para montar un negocio a su señora y asì optener mejores ingresos.

loans.use: Construction of a commercial space in his home, in which to start a second business

loans.name: Clara Luz

texts.es:
Clara Duran lives in the town of Colon-La Libertad and is a single mother with 3 daughters, 2 of whom are studying. Her daughter who doesn't study helps her sell tamales, which is their main source of income. Mrs Duran has been selling typical foods for 15 years, and through this she has been able to build their house and feed her kids. A year ago her eldest daughter was victim of an assault in which a gun wound left her incapacitated for 6 months, which meant that a lot of money that her business had generated went on her recuperation. Even then Mrs Duran did not give up, and she continued fighting hotly to keep going and move forward. She has a good credit record and this will be her first loan with Integral, and she will use it to continue building a septic tank and to install a washbasin to make the house a safer place.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Doña Clara D. vive en el Municipio de Colón-La Libertad, es madre soltera de tres hijas, dos de las cuales están estudiando, la hija que no estudia le ayuda con la venta de tamales, que es su fuente de ingresos principal, la señora D. tiene 15 años de dedicarse a la venta de comida típica, con ello a logrado construir la casa donde vive y darle sustento a sus tres hijas, hace un año su hija mayor fue victima de un asalto que le provoco debido a un disparo quedar incapacitada durante seis meses, teniendo que invertir gran parte de lo que se generaba de dinero en el negocio, para su recuperación, aun así doña Clarita no desfalleció y a luchado arduamente para sobreponerse y lograr salir adelante, Ella a tenido muy buen record crediticio, con Integral será el primer préstamo el cual esta solicitando para continuar con la construcción de una fosa séptica e instalación de un baño lavable para dar más salubridad a la casa.

loans.use: Tp keep building a septic tank and a washbasin/Para continuar con la construcción de una fosa séptica e instalación de un baño lavable

loans.name: Sinecio

texts.es:
Mr. Sinecio L. is from the neighborhood known as 8th of December in the city of San Estanislao. He is 65 years old and is married to Guillermina Wrague, who is 60. They have 6 children, all grown and working independently.

Sinecio has a Ford car in which he works as a taxi driver. He has two stops, one in the municipal market and the other close to the courthouse. The work brings him a good income. The couple has excellent references, both personal and commercial.

Now it is time to add to their home. He would also like to replace his taxi with a newer vehicle.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Sinecio L. es de la Ciudad de San Estanislao, del Barrio 8 de diciembre, tiene 65 años de edad, esta casado con la señora Guillermina Wrague de 60 años de edad, tienen 6 hijos todos mayores de edad y trabajan en forma independientes.

Tiene un automóvil de la marca, Ford en el cual trabaja como taxi de pasajeros, tiene dos paradas, uno en el mercado municipal y otro cerca de la fiscalia, le dà buenos ingresos. Son personas que tienen exelentes referencias, comerciales y personales.

Ahora està mandando ampliar su casa, y màs adelante le gustarìa cambiar su automóvil por otro modelo màs nuevo.

loans.use: Purchase a newer car.

loans.name: César Antonio

texts.es:
Cesar Antonio has his own fast-food business in which he sells hot-dogs, hamburgers, sodas, fried foods, etc. He started this business three years ago with the support of his family and his own savings. With the profits that his business generates he wants to improve his family’s quality of life, and he wants to do it step by step. He will use this loan to buy construction materials so that he can finish the porch of his home, and that way provide more security for his family and their belongings. Cesar hopes to improve his business to provide better attention to his customers and thus continue growing.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva volunteer.

César Antonio es un pequeño comerciante que se gana la vida vendiendo comidas rápidas como hot-dog, hamburguesas, fritangas, refrescos, etc. En busca de una forma de poder salir adelante junto a su familia, decidió hace 3 años poner un negocio de estas ventas. El negocio lo empezó con dinero propio y con el apoyo de su familia. Con los ingresos que le genera el negocio espera poder mejorar el nivel de vida de su familia, y empezará a hacerlo en pequeñas partes, el uso de este crédito será para la compra de materiales de construcción para terminar de hacer el porche de su vivienda, y así poder darle más seguridad a su familia y a sus bienes materiales. César espera poder mejorar el negocio para darles mejor atención a sus clientes, y poder seguir creciendo.

loans.use: To buy construction materials to finish the porch of his house.

loans.name: Marcos Aurelio

texts.es:
Marcos Aurelio works for a local business as a driver and messenger. He lives in the Villa Reconciliación neighborhood. He is 43 years old and married with two children, both still minors at home. His wife takes care of the house and the children. Marcos Aurelio will use the loan to make improvements on his home. With this capital he will build a small room in the front part of his house for the use of the family. Marcos Aurelio plan is to provide his family a dignified home as a way to improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Don Marcos Aurelio trabaja para una empresa como conductor mensajero. Habita en el barrio Villa Reconciliación, tiene 43 años de edad, es casado, con 2 hijos menores de edad, la esposa de Marcos Aurelio es quien se encarga del cuido de la casa y de sus hijos. El uso del préstamo de Don Marcos Aurelio es para mejora de vivienda, con el dinero construirá un pequeño cuarto en la parte delantera de su casa el cual será para uso de la familia. Los planes de Don Marcos Aurelio son poder brindarle a su familia una vivienda digna, y así mejorar el nivel de vida.

loans.use: Construction of a room in his home.

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Elena A. is from Santani and is married with children. She works selling pork. She comments that she has worked in this field for 20 years. She has a small truck in which she does her buying and selling. She is very responsible with her clients. Her current desire is to fit out a store in part of her home and tend to it with her children.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Elena A. es de Santani, tiene 69 años, es casada con hijos. Se dedica a la venta de carnes de cerdos. Comenta que desde hace 20 años trabaja en esta actividad, tiene una camioneta en que realiza su trabajo de compra y venta. Es una señora muy responsable con sus clientes, su anhelo es habilitar una despesa en su domicilio y atender ella con sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase of livestock (pigs)

loans.name: Roberto Genez

texts.es:
Roberto Genez Almirón is from the city of San Estanislao. He is 31 years old and married to Mirta Isabel Maldonado, who is 29.

Their business is milk; they produce 70 liters a day from 4 dairy cows. Roberto also works with a relative for a fixed monthly salary, delivering a variety of commercial merchandise.

Roberto comments that the space he uses for his dairy farm is small for four cows. For this reason he feeds his cows in a neighbor's corral. He would like to expand his dairy farm. He wants to buy another dairy cow as well as forage to better feed the cows, both with an aim to produce more milk each day.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Roberto Genez Almirón es de la ciudad de San Estanislao, tiene 31 años de edad, esta casado con la señora Mirta Isabel Maldonado de 29 años de edad.

Se dedican a la venta de leche, tienen una producciòn de 70 litros por dia, de 4 vacas lecheras. El señor Roberto tambièn trabaja con un pariente en reparto de mercaderias varios de consumo, con un sueldo fijo mensual.

Comentó el cliente que le queda chico su lugar para tener las vacas, es por eso que utiliza el corral de un vecino, para alimentar a los animales, por lo tanto quiere ampliar su tambo. Quiere comprar una vaca lechera y también forrajera para poder alimentar mejor a sus vacas y asi producir mas leche cada dia.

loans.use: Purchase of a dairy cow and forage

loans.name: Zulma

texts.es:
Mrs. Zulma H. O. is from the San Pedro neighborhood of Santaní. She is 43 years old, and has two children.  She runs a grocery and butcher shop with twelve years of experience, and her husband works at a bi-national company. Zulma is very well known in the area as a hardworker and a team player. She wants to buy more consumable merchandise (flour, herbs, sugar) to increase her sales. 

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer. 

La  señora Zulma H. O. es de Barrio San Pedro, calle San José, tiene 43 años, y dos hijos. 
          
Es propietaria de una despensa y carniceria, con 12 años de funcionamiento, su marido trabaja en una empresa Binacional. 

La señora es muy conocida de la zona, por ser muy trabajadora y solidaria con los demàs. Quiere comprar màs mercaderias, de consumo (harina , yerba, azucar ), para poder aumentar sus ventas.

loans.use: Purchase of assorted groceries

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucia is 42 years old. She studied until the first year of high school and speaks the Aymará language and Castilian. She is married and has five children, of which four have already finished studying and are independent and one is with Lucia. Her home is located in the Centro Poblado of Camicachi, in the district of Ilave, which is in the province of El Collao.

Lucia buys and sells sheep that she buys at the fairs in Ilave. Also, she travels twice a month to the Arequipa region with sheep meat and products, like dried potatoes, potatoes, and quinoa, that she sells in different markets. During these trips, Lucia takes the opportunity to visit her children, who she meets in this area.

She belongs to the “22 de Septiembre” community bank, where she took out a loan of 300 new soles, with which she bought four small pigs. With this loan of 2,300 new soles, which she will repay in four months, she will buy ten sheep and two sacks of dried potatoes.

She says that being a member of the community bank taught her to work, to communicate without fear, and to manage her money, for which she is very grateful, as it helps her with loans.

Her dream is to buy a house in Arequipa and to grow her business and expand her merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by A. Shah, Kiva Volunteer.

Lucia tiene 42 años, logró estudiar hasta primero de secundaria, habla el idioma aymará y castellano, es casada, tiene cinco hijos de los cuales cuatro ya terminaron de estudiar y son independientes y solo uno de sus hijos esta a su lado, su domicilio esta ubicado en el Centro Poblado de Camicachi, del Distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao.

Ella se dedica a la compra y venta de ovejas que los compra en las ferias de Ilave, también viaja dos veces al mes a la Región de Arequipa llevando carne de ovino y productos como chuño, papa, Quinua, vendiéndolos en los diferentes mercados y aprovecha para visitar a sus hijos que se encuentran por ese lugar.

Pertenece al Banco Comunal “22 de Septiembre”, donde tuvo un crédito inicial de S/.300.00 nuevos soles, con lo que compro cuatro chanchos pequeños. Con este crédito de S/. 2,300.00 nuevos soles, lo cual lo pagara en cuatro cuotas, comprará diez ovejas y dos sacos de chuño.

Ella manifiesta que siendo socia del Banco Comunal aprendió a trabajar, a comunicarse sin tener miedo, administrar su dinero, por lo que esta muy agradecida con el crédito que se le dio.

El sueño que ella tiene es comprar una casa en Arequipa y crecer en su negocio incrementando su mercadería.

loans.use: To buy sheep and dried potatoes

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucia is 24 years old, and she was able to complete secondary school. She speaks both Spanish and Aymara, and currently lives with her partner and their three children. Two children are in school, and the youngest is in kindergarten. She is from M. and lives in the El Collao province.

Lucia has a printing business called "Imagen" (Image) where she has worked for the last five years. She belongs to the communal bank "22 de Setiembre" (September 22nd) where she got an initial credit of S/. 300.00 nuevo soles which she invested in printing materials such as two boxes of bond paper in various colors.

With this loan for $550, which she will repay in four monthly payments, she will buy five boxes of paper, ink, thread, etc.

She told us that she is learning to be a hardworker, responsible, and united with her companions.

Her greatest wish is to buy a new offset machine and expand her business so that her children can study to become professionals, and then to later be able to buy their house.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Lucia tiene 24 años, logro estudiar secundaria completa, habla el idioma aymará y castellano, actualmente convive con su pareja con quien tiene tres hijos, de los cuales, dos de ellos están en la escuela, y el mas pequeño esta en el jardín, ella es de la Parcialidad de M. y vive en el Jr. Bolognesi de la ciudad de Ilave Provincia de El Collao. Lucia tiene su negocio de imprenta llamada “Imagen” con la que trabaja desde hace cinco años, pertenece al banco Comunal de “22 de Setiembre” donde tuvo un crédito inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles que lo invirtió en la compra de materiales de imprenta como dos cajas papel bond de colores. Con este crédito de S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles, que será pagado en cuatro cuotas; comprará cinco cajas de papel, tinta, telas etc. Ella manifiesta que aprendió a ser trabajadora, responsable y solidaria con sus compañeras. El gran sueño que ella tiene es comprar una nueva maquina offset y ampliar su negocio, para que sus hijos puedan estudiar y ser profesionales, posterior mente comprar su casa.

loans.use: Purchase wholesale paper, ink, and other supplies

loans.name: Justina

texts.es:
Justina is 36 years old, studied until third grade, middle school, she is married and has 5 children who still depend on her. She is a member of “Banco Comunal Andrés Santa Cruz de Chuachua”, of “Centro Poblado de Chuachua”, District of Zepita, Province of Chucuito-Juli and Puno Region. She fattens cattle for a living as with her first loan of S/.300 she bought a cow to fatten. She also sells cheese at the fairs at Desaguadero and Zepita and during winter she sells “tayacha”(typical dish) of “oca” and “izaño” (different kinds of local potatoes) to increase her income. With the loan of S/.1,300 ($475), to be repaid in 4 months, she will buy a “quintal” (46 kg) of “oca”, a “quintal” of “izaño” and a cow to be fattened. Justina had been in the business of “tayacha” for ten years and fattened cattle for one year. Thus she gets her daily income. Her dream is to buy a vehicle to transport cattle, improve her dairy cows and that her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Justina tiene 36 años de edad, estudió hasta tercero de secundaria, es casada y tiene 5 hijos, que aún depende de ella. Es socia del Banco Comunal Andrés Santa Cruz de Chuachua, del Centro Poblado de Chuachua, del Distrito de Zepita, Provincia de Chucuito – Juli y Región de Puno. Se dedica al engorde ganado ya que con su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 nuevos soles compró 1 vaca para el engorde. Ella también vende quesos en las ferias de Desaguadero y Zepita, y en la época de helada vende tayacha de oca e izaño, para tener mayores ingresos económicos. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,300.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará un quintal de oca, un quintal de izaño y 1 vaca para el engorde. Justina indica que hace diez años esta con el negocio de tayacha y el engorde ganado vacuno vienen realizando hace un año. Ya de esa manera cada día genera sus ingresos económicos. Su sueño es comprar carro para traslado de ganado, mejorar sus ganados lecheros y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchase "oca", "izaño" (local products) and 1 cow.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Doña Juana is 45 years old, studied until third graD., elementary, she is married and mother of three children who still depend on her. Presently she makes ropes for a living which she started doing 13 years ago on her own initiative. The ropes are sold at the Sunday fair in the town of Ilave and her stand is located in Jirón Arica s/n. She is a member of the “Banco Comunal Lupakas” of the community of Huariquisana, District of Pilcuyo, Province of El Collao Ilave and Puno Region.

With her previous loans she has succeeded in increasing raw material as well as capital. With this loan of S/.500 ($200), to be repaid in four months, she will buy 150 kilos of hemp to make ropes. Juana is happy as she has increased her capital little by little in order to purchase material to make ropes and furthermore in the “Banco Comunal” she has learned to be responsible, to administer her money, and be punctual. Her future plans are to increase business at the markets of Juliaca, Puno, etc. and make her children study.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Señora Juana tiene 45 años D. edad, estudió hasta tercero D. primaria, es casada y madre D. tres hijos que aun depenD. D. ella. Actualmente se dedica a la actividad D. elaboración D. sogas, este trabajo lo emprendió hace 13 años por iniciativa propia, las sogas las venD. en la feria dominical D. la ciudad D. Ilave y su puesto está ubicada en Jirón Arica s/n. Ella pertenece al Banco Comunal Lupakas D. la comunidad Huariquisana, del distrito D. Pilcuyo, provincia D. El Collao Ilave y Región D. Puno.

Con sus préstamos anteriores ha logrado incrementar su material D. producción y capital. Con este préstamo D. S/.500.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelada en cuatro meses, comprará 150 kilos D. material cáñamo para la elaboración D. sogas. Juana está contenta, ya que poco a poco va incrementando su capital para adquirir más material para elaboración D. sogas y además en el Banco Comunal aprenD. ser responsable, administrar su dinero y puntual en sus actos. Su perspectiva futura es ampliar su negocio en los mercados D. Juliaca, Puno, etc. y hacer estudiar a sus hijos.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of raw material to increase production of rope.

loans.name: Juana Lidia

texts.es:
Mrs. Juana Lidia is 48 years old, married, mother to one child who still depends on her, she studied until fifth grade, middle school, and lives in the community of Huariquisana, District of Pilcuyo, Province of El Collao Ilave and Puno Region. She is a member of “Banco Comunal Lupakas” of the community of Huariquisana where she got her first loan of S/.300. The loan was invested in buying half a packet of raffia to make ropes, which she has been doing for the past 6 years because of lack of a job.

With this loan of S/.1,500 ($550), to be repaid in 4 months, she will purchase two packets of hemp and raffia to make ropes at home and deliver to be sold at the weekly fairs at Ilave and Juliaca as she has weekly orders. Juana Lidia is very happy as her business is growing day by day and she has the possibility of buying packets of material and keep well fed. Therefore she thanks Manuela Ramos for the support to her business. Her vision of the future is to increase capital in order to motorize her machine and that her only son become a professional.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Juana Lidia tiene 48 años de edad, es casada, madre de un hijo que aun depende de ella, logró estudiar quinto de secundaria, vive en la comunidad de Huariquisana, del Distrito de Pilcuyo, Provincia de El Collao Ilave y Región de Puno. Es socia del Banco Comunal Lupakas de la comunidad Huariquisana, en el cual obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 nuevos soles. Este dinero lo invirtió en compra de medio paquete de rafia para elaboración de sojas, esta actividad viene desarrollando hace 6 años atrás por falta de trabajo.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará dos paquetes de material tipo cáñamo y rafia para elaborar sogas en su domicilio y entregar por mayor en las ferias semanales de Ilave y Juliaca, ya que tiene pedidos semanales. Juana Lidia esta muy feliz ya que su negocio crece cada día y tiene posibilidades de adquirir material por paquetes y alimentarse bien. Por lo tanto agradece Manuela Ramos por el apoyo dado para su negocio. Su visión futura es tener más capital, para implantar su maquina de elaboración a motor y su único hijo sea profesional.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of material to increase production of rope.

loans.name: Maria Antonia

texts.es:
María Antonia began her business out of economic need when she could not find work and had nowhere to leave her two children (ages 6 and 10 years) during the day. For that reason, she decided to help a friend of hers to sell cosmetics by catalog. Little by little, she began earning customers, and she decided to go out on her own and sell by herself.

She needs a loan for US $500 that she will repay in six months to purchase merchandise so she can continue in her work.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

María Antonia inicio el negocio porque tenia necesidad económica ya que no encontraba trabajo y además no tenia donde dejar a sus 2 niños (6 y 10 años) por lo que decidió ayudarle a una amiga a vender cosméticos por catalogo poco a poco fue haciendo clientes por lo que prefirió independizarse y vender ella sola.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $500 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancía y poder continuar con su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics for her business

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business #58777

loans.name: Irma  Yolanda

texts.es:
Irma began her business selling out her garage because her husband's pension was no longer enough to cover their expenses. She spent ten years selling clothing outside her home to family and neighbors, then she decided to set up in the flea market selling novelty items as well. When it rains, though, her merchandise gets wet, and it's particularly difficult on hot days when the temperature in the sun can reach upwards of 105 degrees Fahrenheit. That's why she wants to buy and set up an awning, so she and her customers are more comfortable and she can provide them with better service.

She needs a loan for US $500 that she will repay in 6 months to buy an awning for her business. With your help, she will come out ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Irma inicio su negocio vendiendo en la cochera de su casa porque no completaban a pagar sus gastos con la pensión de su esposo. Primero duro 10 años vendiendo ropa afuera de su casa a sus vecinos y familiares, luego se decidió instalarse en la pulga vendiendo aemas novedades, pero cuando llueve se le moja la mercancía, y los días de calor es muy pesado estar a mas de 40 grados centígrados con el sol por eso quiere mandar hacer un toldo, para estar mas cómoda y ofrecerle un mejor servicio a sus clientes.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $500 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar un toldo para su negocio. Con tu apoyo ella saldrá adelante.

loans.use: Purchase an awning for her outdoor market stand.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business #58778

loans.name: Damaris Yasmin

texts.es:
Damaris is married and has two small children, ages 3 and 7. She began her store selling stationery and novelty items two years ago when she had stopped working, and her husband's salary no longer covered their expenses. She opened the stationery store in a small location her mother loaned her and, a little at a time, she has been improving it thanks to the earnings she has obtained.

She needs a loan for $600 that she will repay in 6 months to remodel her shop. With your support, she will come out ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Damaris es casada, y tiene 2 hijos pequeños de 3 y 7 años. Inicio el negocio de papelería y mercería hace 2 años porque dejo de trabajar, y no completaban con el sueldo de su esposo, la papelería la instalo en un localito que le presto su mama, y poco a poco la ha mejorado gracias a las ganancias que esta obteniendo.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $600 que pagara en 6 meses para remodelar su local. Con tu apoyo ella saldrá adelante.

loans.use: Remodel her stationery store

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhorn C., 29, is a farmer who lives in Thnallok Village, Siem Reap Province. She has been farming since 1990 and earns around $3 per day. Her husband, Mr. C. Lam, 30, is also a farmer and a fisherman, who earns around $3 per day. Chhron works hard every day because she takes care of their two children and the family’s expenses. The children are young and in school. Chhorn has a large farm that was contributed by her parents and is her family's main source of income. She is requesting a loan of $1,100 to purchase a plow. This purchase will help Chhorn reduce the cost of plowing for her farmland and enable her to expand her farming business.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase a plow for her farming business

loans.name: Tan

texts.en:
Miss Tan P., 30, grows rice crops and also sells groceries in her village, Anlong Samnor Village, Siem Reap Province. She lives in her family’s home and cares for her father and one sister. She has been selling groceries since 2005 and typically earns around $3.33 per day. Her sister, Miss Tan At, helps with managing the grocery business. To expand their business, she needs capital and is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase more grocery stocks to sell. The loan will allow her to increase her income and keep her business stable.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her grocery business

loans.name: Yem

texts.en:
Mr. Yem Y., 37, is a fisherman in Tonle Sap Lake. He has been fishing since 1992 and typically earns around $4 per day. His wife sells the fish. Their children are young and in school. Because fishing is their main income, Y. must improve his equipment and expand his business to increase his family's income, so he is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a fishing boat.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.name: Moung

His wife, Mrs. Heav Thyvan, is a farmer and cares for three children in the family’s home. They live in Khla Khmom Village, Siem Reap Province. Because Mr. T. is growing his business to meet the increasing demand of customers, he is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase wood to make more furniture for resale.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary, a married woman with six children between the ages of 35 and 50, became a banana seller in 1990. Working daily from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., she can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

Mary now hopes for a loan to buy more  bananas for her business.

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:

Rukia now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes (khanga and vitenge) for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes (khanga and vitenge) for her shop

loans.name: Stella

Stella, a 21-year-old married woman with two children aged five and four, also takes care of  two other children of the same age. A poultry owner since 1998,  she works daily from 7 a.m. to 12 p.m.  and can earn a monthly profit of about $50  from her sales.

Stella now hopes for a loan to buy more poultry for her business.

loans.use: To increase her poultry stock.

loans.name: Saba Din

texts.en:
Saba D. is married with 5 children. He is 40 years old. He has an ice cream shop. He started this business 3 years ago; it is still going very well. He requested and repaid his first loan; it was very useful for Saba D.. He is not alone; one of his sons is working with D.. Some times other members of his family help him.

Now he wants to take out a second loan of 40000 Afghani (US$ 850) with a term of 18 months to buy two new machines for ice cream. This summer he wants to make his business bigger to stand on his feet in the future.

He is happy with the process of loans in Afghanistan. He hopes to help better his family's situation and make a better future for them. He wishes to grow his business in Kabul and open many shops in the next few years. He would like to thank both Kiva and AFSG.

loans.use: To buy two new machines for ice cream

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:

Ansila now hopes for a loan to buy more clothing for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who also has a business in clothing sales.

Lightness now hopes for a loan to buy more poultry for her business.

Mrs. Ung S. and her husband would like to buy fresh black pepper seeds in bulk to increase her yield.

texts.en:

loans.name: Benkadi (‘Union Fait La Force) Group

texts.fr:
The seven women of the Benkadi group are all married with an average age of 45 and an average of 5 children. They live in big traditional families with at least one co-spouse, their husbands, and their children in a Peulh neighborhood (Peulh is a Mali ethnicity) known as Ouassila Wèrè (Ségou Prefecture, Republic of Mali).

This group arose out of a traditional association of mutual aid for times of social events (such as marriages, baptisms, circumcisions, and funerals) and for field work. They sell various articles such as tea, sugar, condiments, fruits and vegetables, cola nuts, and milk.

They buy their goods at the big open-air market of Ségou from wholesalers in the case of articles such as tea, sugar, and condiments. In the case of fruits and vegetables, they buy their goods in the villages surrounding the town of Ségou, notably Konodimini. The sale of these various articles is generally on a cash basis, or on credit, out of their homes or as ambulant salespeople, or at the market. Their clientele is generally men, women, and occasionally children. The very organized members of the Benkadi group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program, from which they are requesting their first loan. With this loan they intend to buy 1 sack of sugar, 1 case of tea, a large quantity of condiments, a tray of cola nuts, and some sacks of fruits and vegetables.

Each of them expects to make a monthly profit of 7,500 FCFA (US$ 18) that they will mainly use to make repayments on the loan, investing the remainder in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les sept (7) femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec au moins une coépouse, leurs époux et leurs enfants dans le quartier peulh (une ethnie du Mali) appelé Ouassila Wèrè (Préfecture de Ségou République du Mali).

Ce groupe est issu d’une association traditionnelle d’entre aide mutuelle lors des événements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes, circoncisions, funérailles) et dans les travaux champêtres. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers comme le thé, le sucre ; les condiments, les fruits et légumes, de la cola et du lait.

Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Ségou auprès des grossistes pour les articles comme le thé le sucre et les condiments. Pour les fruits et légumes c’est dans les villages environnants de la ville de Ségou notamment Konodimini. La vente de ces différents articles se fait généralement au comptant, à crédit, à domicile, de façon ambulante ou au marché. Leurs clientèles sont généralement des hommes, des femmes et quelques fois des enfants. Les membres du groupe Benkadi très organisées ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso, avec lequel elles sont à leur premier prêt. Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt 1 sac de sucre, 1 carton de thé, une importante quantité de condiments, une vane de cola et des sacs de fruits et légumes.

Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel 7 500FCFA qu’elles utiliseront essentiellement à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans les activités.

loans.use:
Purchase of various food items for re-sale

Achat de divers articles alimentaires

loans.name: Mary's Fadhili Group

texts.en:
Mary, a 40-year-old married woman with seven children between the ages of 8 and 20, became a tailor and clothing seller in 1988. Working everyday from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m., she can earn a monthly profit of about $350 from her sales.

Mary now hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling maize, animals, groceries, and bananas respectively.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items for her business.

loans.name: Elice's Haradadi Group

texts.en:
Elice N. is 28 years old. She is a married woman with 2 children, ages 8 and 4. She became a clothes seller in 2002. Every day, she works from 7am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Elice now hopes for a loan of $1350 to buy more clothes (khanga) for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with banana and milk sales, clothes sales, maize and beans and poultry sales .

loans.use: To buy more clothes (khanga) for her business.

loans.name: Esta's Eden Group

texts.en:
Esta M. is 49 years old. She is a married woman with 2 children, ages 17 and 3. Esta owns a small general store, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 7am to 9pm at her business. She can earn a monthly profit of about $350 from her sales.

Esta now hopes for a loan of $525 to buy more commodities for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who has business dealing with banana and milk sales.

loans.use: To buy more commodities to increase her stock

loans.name: Djiguissèmè (Soutien Mutuel) Group

texts.fr:
The 7 members of the Djiguissèmè group are on average 45 years old and have on average 3 children. They all live in monogamous families in the Sokala district of Dagala (Ségou Prefecture, Republic of Mali). They have formed a group because of bonds of friendship and work. The Benkadi Dagala association to which the Djiguissèmè group belongs has been able to take part in a lot of training sessions organized to support rural organizations through the rural loan of the NGO Foundation For International Development Africa.

In searching for financial resources, this group, which had worked with several microfinance institutions, finally decided to join Soro Yiriwaso, through whom they have already received 4 group loans, all reimbursed without difficulty.

With this loan, the members of the Djiguissèmè group plan to purchase 120 wagon loads of firewood, 9 sacks of foodstuffs, and several cases of cosmetics.

They do their purchasing at Dougasso, Zenguela Gachi, and Fombougou, in the case of firewood, from country folk who have a legal permit for this business. The foodstuffs are bought at Dagala, Siguila, and Mèfa. As for the cosmetics, they are purchased in Ségou and sometimes from Lomé (Republic of Togo in West Africa). These articles are generally retailed, for cash or credit, directly from their homes in the village. Their clientele is composed of men and women from their village and surrounding villages.

They hope to make a monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA (around US$ 25) with which they will make repayments on the loan, investing the remainder in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les sept (7) membres du groupe Djiguissèmè ont une moyenne d’age de 45ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles monogamiques au quartier Sokala de Dagala (Préfecture de Ségou République du Mali). Elles se sont regroupées en raison de liens d’amitié et de travail. L’association Benkadi Dagala a laquelle le groupe Djiguisèmè appartient a bénéficié de beaucoup de formations organisées dans le cadre de l’appui aux organisations paysannes à travers le prêt de campagne par l’ ONG FIDA.

Dans sa recherche de ressources financières ce groupe ayant eu à travailler avec plusieurs institutions de microfinance décida de rejoindre finalement Soro Yiriwaso lequel leurs a déjà octroyé 4 prêts de groupe tous remboursés sans difficulté.

Les membres de groupe Djiguissèmè achèteront avec ce prêt , 120 chargements de charrettes de bois de chauffe, 9 sacs de denrées alimentaires et quelques cartons de produits de beauté.

Elles s’approvisionnent à Dougasso, Zenguela Gachi et Fombougou pour le bois de chauffe auprès de paysans ayant une autorisation légale pour cette activité. Les denrées alimentaires sont achetées à Dagala, Siguila et Mèfa quant aux produits de beauté ils sont achetés à Ségou et quelques fois à partir de Lomé (République du Togo en Afrique de l’Ouest). Ces articles sont vendus généralement en détail au comptant et à crédit, à domicile au niveau du village même. La clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes du village et des villages environnants.

Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 10.000 FCFA. avec lequel elles payeront les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans l’activité.

loans.use:
Purchase of firewood, grocery products, and cosmetics

Achat de bois de chauffe, de denrées alimentaires et de produits de beauté

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha E. is a married woman with 4 children ages 20, 14, 12 and 4. She became a milk seller in 1990. Every day, she works from 8am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Martha now hopes for a loan of $275 to buy more milk for her business.

loans.name: Amela

texts.en:
Amela is a 37-year-old woman living in a village outside the town of Visoko. She is married and her husband works as an officer in the army. Amela spends a lot of her time breeding chickens, and she has 50 right now. She is able to make income by selling the eggs they produce, which she takes to a wholesale retailer who distributes them to local stores.

She is requesting this loan, her 1st loan with Žene za Žene, in the amount of 1000 KM (US$ 800) to further invest in this poultry business. She wants buy some more chickens and also purchase more food for them, and she hopes she can increase her profits by selling even more eggs.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and more chicken food

loans.name: Pili's Ufunuo Group

texts.en:
Pili N. is 28 years old. She is a married woman with a 2 year old child. She became a coconut seller in 2004. Every day she works from 9am to 6pm at her business. She can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Pili now hopes for a loan of $875 to buy more coconuts for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who have businesses dealing with maize sales, and rice sales.

loans.use: To buy more coconut for her business.

loans.name: Sabougnouman (Le Porte Bonheur Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Sabougnouman group are on average 35 and have an average of 4 children. They live in polygamous households with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in the Ouassila Wèrè neighborhood of the village of Ouassila, Ségou Prefecture (Republic of Mali). These women are linked by professional ties, by kinship, by friendship and by being neighbors. They essentially sell condiments, cereals, fresh cow’s milk, and firewood. These businesses often function daily (milk sales) or spread out over time (sales of cereals, wood, and condiments).

In order to satisfy the ever increasing demands of their clientele, they decided to join the credit program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso which agreed to grant them their first group loan. The women of the group often do their procurement of goods directly in Ouassila (dried grains and fresh cow’s milk), sometimes in surrounding villages (such as Konodimini in the case of firewood) and the regional capital Ségou (for condiments and rice).

With this loan they intend to buy350 liters of fresh cow’s milk, 300 kg of dried cereals and legumes (millet, beans, peanuts, etc.), 4 wagon loads of firewood and 285 kg of condiments and of rice.

Their sales are generally retail, for cash or on credit, on market days, in the village square, and out of their homes (night and day). The clientele generally consists of women and men who come from other villages to make their purchases in Ouassila. The group members expect to make a monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA (about US$ 25).

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Sabougnouman ont en moyenne 35 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des foyers polygames avec leurs maris coépouses et enfants dans le quartier Ouassila Wèrè du village de Ouassila préfecture de Ségou (république du Mali.) Ces femmes sont liées par des relations professionnelles, de parenté, d’amitié et de voisinage. Elles font essentiellement le commerce de condiments alimentaires, de céréales, de lait frais de vache et du bois de chauffe. Les activités menées sont souvent quotidiennes (le lait) ou étalées dans le temps (les céréales, le bois et les condiments).

Afin de satisfaire une demande de plus en plus croissante de la clientèle, elles décidèrent d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso qui accepta de leurs accorder leur premier prêt. Les femmes de groupe se ravitaillent souvent sur place à Ouassila (en céréales sèches et lait frais de vache), parfois dans les villages environnants (tel Konodimini en bois de chauffe) et dans la capitale régionale Ségou (en condiments alimentaires et en riz).

Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt : 350 litres de lait frais de vache (vente quotidienne), 300 kg de céréales sèches (mil haricot arachide etc.) 4 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe et 285 kg de condiments et de riz.

Les ventes sont effectuées généralement en détail, au comptant et à crédit les jours de foires, sur la place publique du village et à domicile (nuit et jour). La clientèle généralement constituée de femmes et d’hommes se déplace des autres villages pour venir faire des achats à Ouassila. Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 10.000FCFA.

loans.use:
Purchase of milk, cereals, firewood, and condiments for re-sale

Achat de lait, de céréales, de bois de chauffe et de condiments

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mery

texts.en:
Mery E. is a married woman with 4 children ages 17, 13, 9 and 3. She became a poultry seller in 1988. Every day she works from 12pm to 7pm at her business. She can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Mery now hopes for a loan of $275 to buy more poultry for her business.

loans.use: To buy more poultry for her business.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is a 27-year-old woman from the small village of Kralupi, which is located near the town of Visoko. She is married, with three children, ages one, five and nine years. Her husband works in a poultry factory, and they receive a small child welfare allowance monthly to supplement their income.

Alma is requesting this 4th loan with Žene za Žene to buy food for her cows. She has one cow, and earns income now by selling milk to one of the large dairy factories in a nearby town. She wants to purchase some high quality food for her cow, so that it will produce better milk.

Since costs for food are at an all time high, Alma believes this will be a good investment right now. If she earns enough from these milk sales, she hopes to save enough to buy another cow.

loans.use: To buy food for her cow

loans.name: Ladriya (Loyauté) Group

texts.fr:
The seven women who make up the Ladriya group are all married, 32 years old on average, with an average of 4 children. The majority live in monogamous families in Dagala Wèrè, one of the villages of Ségou (the fourth economic region of the Republic of Mali).

They mostly are involved in food service, the sale of cereals, the sale of firewood, and of toilet soap. The members of the Ladriya group have ties of friendship and work-related bonds. Because of their mutual confidence, they decided to become members of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their first loan. This loan will serve to purchase: 12 sacks of cereals, of which 2 sacks of millet will be reserved for transformation into dried couscous, and 4 wagon loads of firewood.

These women do their purchasing essentially in Dagala wèrè itself (in the case of cereals and firewood, for which they pay 800 FCFA, about US$ 2, per wagonload to the department responsible for nature conservation) and in Ségou in the case of ingredients for food service.

They generally make their sales retail, in their homes, on the market days of surrounding villages (for cash and on credit) and in Soro wèrè (an encampment of peulhs—an ethnicity in Mali). Their clientele is made up of shepherds and market-day merchants. They expect to make a monthly average profit of 10,000 FCFA (about US$ 25) which will be used to make repayments on the loan, the remainder being invested in the businesses.

N.B. Kadiatou D. is absent from the photo because she was away attending a funeral.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les sept (7) femmes du groupe Ladriya sont toutes mariées, ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 4 enfants et vivent en majorité dans des familles monogames à Dagala Wèrè un des villages de Ségou (la quatrième région économique de la république du Mali).

Elles exercent en majorité la restauration, la vente des céréales, la vente du bois de chauffe et de savon de toilette. Les membres du groupe Ladriya ont des liens d’amitié et professionnels. En raison de la confiance mutuelle, elles décidèrent d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier prêt. Ce prêt servira à acheter : 12 sacs de grains de céréales dont 2 sacs de mil réservés à la transformation en couscous séché, 4 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe.

L’approvisionnement de ces femmes se fait essentiellement sur place à Dagala wèrè (en céréales et en bois de chauffe où elles payent 800 FCFA par chargement de charrette aux services de la conservation de la nature) et à Ségou pour les matières premières de la restauration.

Elles effectuent généralement leurs ventes en détail à domicile, dans les foires des villages environnants (au comptant et à crédit) et à Soro wèrè (un campement de peulhs). La clientèle est constituée de bergers et de forains. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 10.000FCFA, qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans les activités.

NB : La nommée Kadiatou D. est absente de la photo pour raison sociale (décès).

loans.use:
Purchase of cereals and firewood

Achat de céréales et de bois de chauffe

loans.name: Kolaban (Le Terminus) Group

texts.fr:
The eight members of the Kolaban group are all married, have an average age of 44 and on average 4 children. They live in big traditional families, generally with at least one co-spouse, in the Sokala neighborhood of Dagala (Ségou Prefecture, Republic of Mali).

They sell plastic utensils, cereals, firewood, etc. They do their purchasing generally on market days, from rural people and merchants who come in from the big cities.

These women, very expert in economic affairs thanks to their collaborations with several development agencies, have decided to remain with Soro Yiriwaso, which has already given them 4 group loans. The Kolaban group correctly reimbursed all the preceding loans.

This present loan will be used to buy 45 sacks of cereals (in the villages of Dagala and surroundings, Siguila and Mèfa), 125 wagon loads of firewood from the rural people in Dougasso, Zenguela, Gachi and Fombougou, and plastic kitchen utensils from wholesalers in the town of Ségou.

The sacks of cereals are sold to wholesalers in Ségou. On the other hand, the other items are sold in the village for cash, on credit, retail out of their homes or as ambulant saleswomen. Their clientele is made up of men and women. In the final reckoning, they expect to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 FCFA (about US$ 36) which they essentially wish to invest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les huit (8) membres du groupe Kolaban sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 44 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles généralement avec au moins une coépouse dans le quartier Sokala de Dagala (Préfecture de Ségou République du Mali).

Elles exercent le commerce d’ustensiles en plastiques, de céréales, de bois de chauffe etc. Elles s’approvisionnent habituellement les jours de foire auprès de paysans et des commerçants venant des grandes villes.

Ces femmes très expertes dans les activités économiques grâce à leurs collaborations avec plusieurs structures de développement ont décidé de rester avec Soro Yiriwaso lequel leurs à déjà accordé 4 prêts de groupe .Le groupe Kolaban a correctement remboursé tous les prêts précédents.

Ce prêt actuel servira à acheter 45 sacs de céréales (dans les villages de Dagala et alentours, Siguila et Mèfa), 125 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe auprès des paysans à Dougasso, Zenguela, Gachi et Fombougou et des ustensiles de cuisine en plastiques auprès de grossistes de la ville de Ségou.

Les sacs de céréales sont vendus à des grossistes à Ségou. Par contre les autres articles sont vendus au village au comptant, à crédit, en détail à domicile ou en ambulant. La clientèle est constituée d’hommes et de femmes .Au bout du compte, elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000 FCFA avec lequel elles souhaitent essentiellement investir dans les activités.

loans.use:
Purchase of firewood, plastic utensils, and cereals

Achat de bois de chauffe, d’ustensiles en plastiques et de céréales.

loans.name: Siguitèmasson (C’Est Le Travail Qui Paye) Group

texts.fr:
The six members of Siguitèmasson group are an average 41 years old and have on average 4 children. They live in traditional extended families with their husbands and co-spouses, parents-in-law, brothers and sisters, and their children in the Ouassila Wèrè section of the village of Ouassila, Ségou Prefecture (Republic of Mali). The members of the Siguitèmasson group are linked by bonds of kinship and friendship. In view of their mutual confidence, they decided to ask for a loan from Soro Yiriwaso. This is their first group loan (jointly liable loan) with the institution, after a series of four training courses.

The members of the Siguitèmasson group sell firewood, cereals, soap, and yams. With the loan they expect to buy 3 cartloads of firewood, 150 kg of cereals, 1 sack of yams, ½ sack of locally fabricated soap, 2 cases of detergent. They buy the firewood locally (they have a permit allowing them to cut wood, issued by the office responsible for nature conservation of Ségou). As for the cereals, they purchase them in neighboring villages (such as Konodimini). The soap and the yams are bought in Ségou.

The sale of these articles is generally done in the village, retail, for cash and on credit out of their homes and on the village square. The wood is sold in Ségou or to merchants coming from Ségou. Their clients are generally women and a few men.

They hope to have an average monthly profit of 6,000 FCFA (about US$ 15) that they will use to help their husbands pay family expenses, investing any remainder in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les six (6) membres du groupe Siguitèmasson ont une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris des coépouses les beaux parents les frères et sœurs et leurs enfants dans le quartier Ouassila Wèrè du village de Ouassila, préfecture de Ségou (république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Siguitèmasson sont liés par des liens de parenté et d’amitié. En raison de la confiance mutuelle, elles ont décidé de solliciter un prêt auprès de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe (crédit solidaire) avec l’institution. Après une série de quatre formations.

Les membres du groupe Siguitèmasson, exercent le commerce du bois de chauffe, des céréales, des savons et des tubercules. Avec le prêt elles comptent acheter 3 chargements de charrette, 150 kg de céréales 1sac de tubercule, 1/2 sac de savon de fabrication locale, 2 cartons de savon de lessives. Elles s’approvisionnent sur place en bois de chauffe (elles deteinnent un permis de coupe de bois délivré par les services compétents de la conservation de la nature de Ségou). Pour les céréales, elles achètent dans les villages voisins (tel Konodimini). Pour le savon, les tubercules les achats se font à Ségou.

La vente de ces articles se fait généralement au village en détail au comptant et à crédit à domicile et sur la place publique du village. Par contre le bois est vendu à Ségou ou à des commerçants venant de Ségou. Leurs clients sont généralement des femmes et quelques hommes.

Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 6.000FCFA qu’elles utiliseront à aider leurs maris à subvenir aux charges de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.

loans.use:
Purchase and splitting of firewood; cereals; soap and yams

Achat et coupe de bois de chauffe ; céréales ; des savons et des tubercules.

loans.name: Dembagnouman (La Bonne Maman) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Dembagnouman group are, on average, 42 years old with 4 children. They live in large, extended, traditional families with their husbands, brothers, sisters, in-laws, children and generally their husbands’ other wives. They live in three different areas of the village of Dagala (Region of Ségou, Republic of Mali): N’Tokorola, Nakolobala and Famabougou. The women in the group were primarily brought together by professional ties, as they all serve food and sell firewood and grains. In order to meet the demand of their growing clientele, they decided together to join the loan program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are receiving their first loan. With this loan, they intend to purchase 18 cartloads of firewood in Dougasso, Zenguena, Gachin and Fambougou (from farmers who have permits to chop down trees), 75 kg of rice and a large quantity of condiments for their food service business at the Ségou market. They generally sell the firewood at retail prices and for cash in the regional capital, Ségou, both door-to-door and at the market. Their clientele is made up of men and women who own restaurants and bakeries. The rice and condiments are used to make dishes that are sold to customers at the market. They hope to earn an average monthly profit of 5,500 CFA francs, which they will use to repay the interest on the loan and increase their capital.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Les membres de Dembagnouman ont une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris, les frères, les sœurs, les beaux parents, les enfants et généralement des coépouses. Elles habitent trois quartiers différents : N’Tokorola, Nakolobala et Famabougou du village de Dagala (Région de Ségou République du Mali). Les femmes du groupe sont essentiellement liées par un lien professionnel et exercent la restauration, le commerce de bois de chauffe de céréales. Afin de faire face aux demandes de la clientèle de plus en plus croissantes, elles décidèrent ensemble d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur premier prêt. Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt 18 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe à Dougasso, Zenguena, Gachin et Fombougou (auprès de paysans ayant une autorisation de coupe de bois), 75kg de riz et une importante quantité de condiments pour la restauration au marché de la ville de Ségou. Tandis que les bois de chauffe sont vendus dans la capitale régionale Ségou d’une façon ambulante, au marché généralement au comptant et en détail. La clientèle est constituée de femmes et d’hommes, des restauratrices et des boulangers. Le riz et les condiments sont utilisés pour faire des plats vendus aux individus fréquentant le marché Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 5.500 FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et à renforcer le fonds de commerce.

loans.use: Purchase of firewood, rice and condiments

loans.name: Soutoura (La Protection) Group

texts.fr:
The majority of the women in the Soutoura group are married and are, on average, 48 years old with 6 children. They live in large, traditional, polygamous families in the Bagadadji area of the city of Ségou (Republic of Mali). They normally sell condiments, soap, firewood, clothing and shoes, and they also make clothing. The members of the Sountoura group were brought together by partnership, age and neighborly relations. Together they decided to request their first loan from Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan, they would like to purchase 30 meters of fabric, 30 children’s clothing items, 20 pairs of shoes, a large quantity of condiments, 1 box of cosmetic soap, 20 cartloads of firewood, etc. They buy the firewood from farmers who have permits to cut down trees in the villages around Ségou. They purchase the other items at the market in Ségou or in Bamako (the capital of Mali). They sell their products for cash, most often at the Ségou market or at the weekly markets in the villages around Ségou, generally at retail prices and for cash, to a primarily female clientele. They intend to earn an average monthly profit of 13,500 CFA francs, which they will use to repay the interest on the loan and reinvest the rest in their business. In the future, they would like to purchase an embroidery machine to improve the quality of their clothing.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Les femmes du groupe Soutoura, à majorité mariées, ont un âge moyen de 48 ans et ont 6 enfants. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles polygamiques au quartier Bagadadji de la ville de Ségou (République du Mali).
