loans.use: Additional capital to purchase more fish in bulk to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Diep's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Trần Thi Điệp (MS: 11040032) is 40 years old. She is a cadre helping the women of the hamlet. Her family has quite many activities. Her husband is a cadre of the village and she works for the community in the fields, retailing and providing agricultural services. Today, she needs a loan of 3.186.000 VND for retailing. She has some seed capital, but she decided to participate to the Fund because of the convenient payment terms and conditions.

The other members of the group are:

  • Trần Thị Ánh (MS: 11040033), borrowing 3.186.000 VND to buy and sell fruit
  • Nghiêm Thị Quyên (MS: 11040034), borrowing 3.186.000 VND to buy pig feed
  • Nguyễn Thị Phượng (MS: 11040035), borrowing 3.186.000 VND to buy pig feed
  • Nguyễn Thị Mai (MS: 11040036), borrowing 3.186.000 VND to buy more pigs to breed

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Minh, Kiva volunteer

    Chị Trần Thi Điệp (MS: 11040032), năm nay 40 tuổi. Là cán bộ phụ nữ thôn. Gia đình chị có khá nhiều hoạt động. Chồng là cán bộ xã, chị vừa công tác xã hội lại làm ruộng bán hàng (cung cấp dịch vụ nông nghiệp ...). Nay chị đã vay 3.186.000 VND để bổ xung vốn bán hàng.Chị đã được tiếp cận khá nhiều nguồn vốn nhưng nay vì thích hình thức tiết kiêm để hoàn trả của tài chính vi mô bình minh nên đã tham gia.

    Các thành viên khác trong nhóm:

  • Trần Thị Ánh (MS: 11040033), vay 3.186.000 VND để bán hàng hoa quả
  • Nghiêm Thị Quyên (MS: 11040034), vay 3.186.000 VND để mua cám lợn
  • Nguyễn Thị Phượng (MS: 11040035), vay 3.186.000 VND để mua cám lợn
  • Nguyễn Thị Mai (MS: 11040036), vay 3.186.000 VND để lấy vốn đi chợ và mua lợn giống

loans.use: Retailing and breeding

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia A. sells banku, a local meal that she prepares. The maize she uses for the preparation of the food is normally bought on credit. Cecilia is a single parent with 6 children.

Cecilia has many customers, and she wants to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for a loan so she can purchase more maize.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business selling banku.

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en:
Alberta N. is a fishmonger. She is married. Her husband is a nurse, but his income is not sufficient to support Alberta and her 2 children.

Alberta has many customers, and she wants to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for a loan to provide additional capital to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her fish selling business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia A. is a fish monger. She is a single parent, and her income is not sufficient to support Cecilia and her child.

She has many customers, and she wants to expand her business to increase her profits. She is asking for a loan for additional capital to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her fish-selling business.

loans.name: Miriam's Omega Group

texts.en:
Miriam is 30 years old, married and has a one-year-old child. She is also raising another child who is four years old. Miriam makes a living running a shop where she sells tomatoes. Every day, she works from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

Miriam has applied for a loan to buy more tomatoes to sell to her customers. She will share this loan with the other members of her group, who run businesses selling bananas, vegetables and clothing. The fifth member of her group works as a seamstress.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of items to sell.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena is 31 years old, single and has a child who is eight years old. She makes a living selling clothing and animal feed, a business she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $155 from her sales.

Magdalena has applied for a loan to buy more animal feed to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of items to sell

loans.name: Ry

texts.en: Mrs. Ry C. is a farmer in Chrork Sangkai Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her husband, Mr. Kong Prum, is a firewood and coal seller. Mrs. Ry C. is 45 years old and the mother of eight children, three of whom are employed in different business activities while the remaining five are attending school.  Her plantation revenue is too small because she just owns a small rice field.  Mrs. Ry C. requests a loan to buy more rice field to expand her rice revenue. Previously, Mrs. Ry C. had obtained a loan from AMK to buy a cart in order to transport to resell door-to-door and she has fully paid it back.

loans.use: To buy more rice field.

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is 37 years old, married and has three children ages 12, 9 and 2. She became a banana seller in 2003. Every day, she works from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

Ester has applied for a loan to buy more bananas to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more bananas to sell.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mrs. Mao S. is a 46-year-old married mother with five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory and another is working in a coal kiln. The remaining three are attending the local school. Mrs. Mao S. is a villager in Kraing Kantrol Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a farmer and her husband, Mr. Chea Loek, owns a coal kiln where he can produce coal in order to sell. Because she does not have enough animals to plow her rice field, Mrs. Mao S. requests a loan to buy a cow to add to the old one to plow the field. Previously, Mrs. Mao S. had obtained a loan from AMK to buy the other cow and she has fully paid it back.

loans.use: To buy a cow to add to the old one to plow the field.

loans.name: Thoeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Thoeurn S. is a 49-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is a pig breeder while the other transports firewood to sell door-to-door.  Mrs. Thoeurn S. is a farmer in Kraing Sromor Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her rice revenue now is very small because she owns a small rice field; thus, Mrs. Thoeurn S. requests a loan to buy more land in order to expand her rice production.

loans.use: To buy more land in order to expand her rice revenue.

loans.name: Thol

texts.en: Mrs. Thol H. is 21 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study.  Mrs. Thol H. is a grocer in Tlok Roloeurng Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her husband, Mr. Thorn Thaing, sells firewood. Since his business is going well, Mrs. Thol H., asks for a loan to buy a cart in order to sell firewood door-to-door.

loans.use: To buy a cart to sell firewood door-to-door.

loans.name: Eliafile's Ailanga Group

texts.en:
Eliafile is 40 years old, married and has five children ages 22, 20, 17, 15 and 9. In 2002, she went into business selling bananas. Every day, she works from 8.30 a.m. to 6.30 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Eliafile has applied for a loan to buy more bananas to sell. She will share this loan with the other members of her group, who run businesses selling maize, milk and bananas.

loans.use: To buy more bananas to sell.

loans.name: Las Mercedes Group

texts.es:
The Las Mercedes committee was formed more than two years ago and is in it's 7th cycle. The group operates in the Paraguayan town of San Lorenzo. The women who run general stores have their businesses in their houses; the others sell clothing, medicines and food, some working from home and others going door to door.

Because Las Mercedes is a committee, they have a history of repaying their loans on time to both the Fundacion Paraguay and within the group. They now have savings of GS.1,500,000 on deposit at a local Cooperative. Moreover, they sponsor activities such as raffles and food sales to support a Caja D. Auxilio (savings fund) account set asiD. to help members who are ill or to repay the Fundacion for loans to the group.

For this cycle, it's important to note the commitment of these women to improving their lives. The support of the group has been a fundamental reason for the growth of their businesses and, with it, their self-esteem which has developed as they've taken control of their lives. The strengthening of Paraguayan families is an important consequence.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

El comité LAS mercedes se formó hace ya más D. dos año, son un grupo que esta en 7mo Ciclo. Pertenecen a la zona D. Laurelty San LORENZO. Las señoras se dedican las que tienen su negocio en su casa a la Despensa, las demás hacen venta D. ropas, remedios y comidas, algunas en su casa y otras recorren D. puerta en puerta.

Como grupo es un comité que estable pagar con puntualidad sus cuotas en la Fundación y dentro del grupo también, poseen un Ahorro D. GS.1.500.000, que lo depositan en una Cooperativa D. la zona. Ademas realizan actividades en conjunto como rifas y venta D. comidas tipicas para lograr un fondo D. Caja D. Auxilio para los casos que alguien se enferme , o poder adelantar sus pagos como grupo en la Fundación.

En este ciclo se nota la dedicaciòn D. las señoras por salir adelante y el apoyo D. su grupo ha sido fundamental para hacerlas crecer en su actividades económicas y también en su autoestima que se ha desarrollado por la forma en que ellas son protagonistas e importantes con su trabajo en el grupo.Y un punto muy importante el fortalecimiento D. los hogares paraguayos.

loans.use:
For those operating general stores, the purchase of meat, cheese, vegetables and cleaning products.  For those selling clothing, the purchase of clothing for adults and children.  For those women selling food, investments in other businesses such as cosmetics.  Some of those selling beverages would also like to sell ice cream and cold drinks.  The women who 
work as seamstresses will buy material and the other supplies they need to provide their services.

loans.name: Rahel's Sayuni Group

texts.en:
Rahel is 48 years old, married and has three children ages 30, 25 and 15. She went into business selling clothes in 2005. Every day, she works from 10 a.m. to midnight at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Rahel has applied for a loan to buy more clothes to sell. She will share this loan with the other member of her group, who makes a living running a cafe.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Emiliana's Nazareti Group

texts.en:
Emiliana is 22 years old, married and has a child who is one year old. She also cares for another child who is three. Emiliana owns a small general store, which she opened last year. Every day, she works from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Emiliana has applied for a loan to buy more commodities to sell in her store. She will share this loan with the members of her group, who run businesses selling maize, milk and beans.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of items to sell

loans.name: Thi Sen's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Chị Đặng thị Sen is 30 years old. Her family cooks vegetarian food. Her group already had one 6-month lending cycle, which has already been paid back very well. This time, she wants to borrow 2.478.000 VND to buy statues for sell.

In her group, there are also:

  • Mrs. Nguyễn thị Hồng, borrowing 2.478.000 VND to cook vegetarian food.
  • Mrs. Đặng thị Thúy, borrowing 2.006.000 VND to buy cast iron to make pots
  • Mrs. Mẫn thị Lượng, borrowing 2.478.000 VND to buy cooking supplies for Vietnamese desserts
  • Mrs. Nguyễn thị Tất, borrowing 2.478.000 VND to cook vegetarian food

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Minh, Kiva volunteer

    Chị Đặng thị Sen năm nay 30 tuổi.Gia đình chị làm đồ chay.Chị cùng nhóm đã được một chu kỳ vay 6 thang và đã hoàn trả vốn vay rất tốt . Đợt này chị vay 2.478.000 VND về mua đồ tượng để làm hàng.

    Trong nhóm chị có:

  • Chị Nguyễn thị Hồng vay 2.478.000 VND để làm đồ chay.
  • Chị Đặng thị Thúy vay ở mức 2.006.000 VND để mua gang về đúc nồi
  • Chị Mẫn thị Lượng vay 2.478.000 VND mua đồ nấu chè
  • Chị Nguyễn thị Tất vay mức 2.478.000 VND để làm đồ chay

loans.use: Cooking and pot casting

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
This group from Santo Domingo emerged through another committee in the same neighborhood. All of the women carry out productive activities by selling merchandise at the international bridge (oil, flour, sugar, soap, noodles, and other food products). They also sell clothing and lingerie. One woman has a business of raising chickens, and others have their own businesses in their home (a grocery store and a kiosk). The amount that each woman will receive varies from 300,000 to 500,000 guaranis ($75-100). All of the women will purchase merchandise for the activities they presently carry out.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Este grupo de Santo Domingo surgió por medio de otro comité formado en el mismo barrio. Todas las señoras realizan actividades productivas venta de mercaderias en el puente internacional (aceites, harinas, azucar, jabon en polvo, fideos y otros productos comestibles) tambien venden ropas y lencerias Una señora tiene negocio de cria de pollos y otras negocios propios en su domicilio( despensa, Kiosko). El monto que recibe cada señora varia de 300.000 a 500.000, todas las señoras destinan el crédito para comprar mercaderias para las actividades que ya estan realizando actualmente.

loans.use: Purchase of eggs, oil, wine, soap, sugar, noodles, rice, flour, dairy products, chickens to raise, clothing, and lingerie.

loans.name: Mujeres Trabajadoras Group

texts.es:
The “Working Women” Committee is located in the city of Ypane. Working Women is one of the committees that maintain an excellent organization and with the passage of time have demonstrated a great deal of organizational capacity. All of the members of the committee are mothers and workers. In the photo, all members (except for one) are pictured.

The members have their own activities, although some of them have formal jobs and develop their entrepreneurship in their free time in order to increase their income. Among them are some that own small stores, others sell clothing, still others sell fruit and vegetables, raise pigs and chickens, sell food, run bars and restaurants, work as seamstresses, sell charcoal, cakes and sweets. The committee is very well organized and does various formal activities together in order to strengthen their unity and solidarity. For every loan that the Paraguay Foundation awards them, the committee members invest the money in order to grown their small businesses with the goal of sustained development.

The committee has existed for two years and in that time and with successive loans granted to the committee, the members have succeeded in developing their entrepreneurship in a general manner.

The loan that every one of the members will receive from the Paraguay Foundation will be invested in the purchase of various articles, the majority of them merchandise for the activities of the committee’s members. Some of these articles are: meat, sugar, rice, vegetables, milk products, drinks, animals, charcoal, fabric, thread, etc. Each member of the committee will use their loan for their corresponding work or business.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

El Comité “Mujeres Trabajadoras” se encuentra en la ciudad de Ypane. Mujeres Trabajadoras es uno de los comités que mantiene una organización excelente y con el correr del tiempo han demostrado bastante capacidad organizativa. Todas las integrantes del comité son madres y trabajadoras. En la fotografía tomada, se encuentran las todas las integrantes del comité.

Las integrantes tienen sus actividades propias, aunque algunas tienen trabajos formales y desarrollan sus emprendimientos en un tiempo extra para acrecentar sus ingresos, entre estas están algunas que poseen despensas, otras venden ropas, otras venden frutas y verduras, cría de chanchos y gallinas, venta de comidas, bares y comedores, costureras, vendedoras de carbón y vendedoras de tortas y dulces. El comité esta muy bien organizado y realiza diversas actividades extras a las formales del programa para fortalecer su unidad y solidaridad. En cada préstamo que le otorga la Fundación Paraguaya las integrantes del comité invierten para acrecentar sus microempresas con el fin de lograr un desarrollo sostenido.

El comité se encuentra funcionando desde hace dos años, en dicho tiempo y con los sucesivos créditos otorgados a este comité, sus integrantes han logrado desarrollar sus emprendimientos de manera gradual.

Los créditos que recibirán cada una de la Fundación Paraguaya serán invertidos en la compra de varios artículos, la mayoría de ellos, mercaderías para las actividades de las integrantes del comité. Algunos de estos artículos son: carnes, azúcar, arroz, verduras, lácteos, bebidas, animales, carbón vegetal, telas, hilos etc. Cada una de las integrantes del comité destina el crédito de acuerdo a lo correspondiente a su actividad económica.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise such as meat, sugar, rice, milk products, drinks, animals, charcoal, fabric, thread, clothing, fruit and vegetables, etc.Compra de mercaderías como carnes, azúcar, arroz, verduras, lácteos, bebidas, animales, carbón vegetal, telas, hilos, ropas, frutas y verduras,  etc.

loans.name: Nargis

texts.ru:
Nargis S. has three children. Her husband works as a handyman. He contracts out his services and there are days when he is not working.

Nargis needs to work without taking any days off. She sells candy and other sweets at the market. Currently she purchases products from wholesalers on credit and pays them back after selling the products. Nargis has to wait until she sells her inventory before getting additional products to sell. She learned about KIVA and has turned to MicroInvest for a loan, which will allow her to pay back her suppliers up front.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Наргис замужем имеет троих детей, ее муж работает мастером ремонтных услуг. У него сдельная работа, бывает дни когда он не работает. Ей приходиться работать без выходных. Она продает на рынке конфеты и другие сладости. Ее снабжают поставщики около 10 % товаром. Ей это помогало продавать сначала товар , а потом расплачиваться с поставщиками. Сейчас она узнала об кредите КИВА и обратилась в Микроинвест, что бы наличными расплачиваться с поставщиками. Также она приобретает конфеты по мере возможности, т.е, когда у нее есть реализация (это получается в неделю 2 раза)на эти деньги она приобретает товар.

loans.use: Purchase candy for sale

loans.name: Pascasie

texts.en:
Greetings from Gisenyi, Rwanda! Pascasie is 52 years old, married with 10 children and 6 adopted orphans from the 1994 Genocide in Rwanda.

She operates her small shop selling various home consumption items like cassava flour, maize flour, soap, salt, beans, paraffin, match boxes, etc. She earns about $ 60 every month. Through the profit from her business, Pascasie has been able to renovate her house. She employs 5 people in her business. She is requesting this loan in order to buy more stock for her business.

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Prosperidad Group

texts.es:
The Prosperity Committee formed as a union of neighbors in the Las Garzas neighborhood in the city of San Antonio. At first, the committee had bad experiences with the program, since they had some people who didn't fulfill their responsibilities, but now they have recuperated their confidence and their solidarity. Prosperity is one of the committees that has succeedeed with good organization and stability in this city. They are only on their fourth loan, but in this time they have demonstrated a lot of capacity to work as a team. In this photograph are 15 of the 16 members of the committee. All of the members have their own activities. Although some have formal jobs, they carry out their businesses in their extra time to increase their income. The committee has a very harmonious relationship among all of their members, and they have demonstrated their unity on various occasions. The carry out their activities as a group, such as solving any inconvenience by making a majority decision.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

El Comitè “Prosperidad” se formò a partir de la union de vecinas del barrio Las Garzas de la ciudad de San Antonio, en un principio, el comité tuvo malas experiencias con el programa, teniendo en el comité a personas que no cumplian con su responsabilidad, pero hoy ha recuperado la confianza y la solidaridad. “Prosperidad” es uno de los comites que ha logrado una buena organización y estabilidad en dicha ciudad, si bien solamente estan con el cuarto ciclo, en este tiempo han demostrado bastante capacidad de trabajar en equipo. En la fotografia tomada se encuentran 15 de las 16 integrantes del comite. Todas las integrantes tienen sus actividades propias, aunque algunas tienen trabajos formales, desarrollan sus emprendimientos en un tiempo extra para acrecentar sus ingresos. El comité lleva la mas armoniosa relacion entre todas sus miembros y han demostrado su unidad en varias ocasiones, ya sea desarrollando actividades en forma conjunta, como solucionando cualquier inconveniente siempre bajo la decisión de la mayoría.

loans.use: The credits received from Fundación Paraguaya were invested in the purchase of various items, the majority of which were supplies or merchandise for the committee members' activities.  Some of these items are: meat, beverages, rice, pasta, etc.  These articles were purchased by the women who are dedicated to sales, such as those who have grocery stores.  Those who are dedicated to other trades used their credits to purchase supplies for their activities:  thread, fabric, chemical products, etc.

loans.name: Santa Teresa Group

texts.es:
The Santa Teresa committee is a group of very dynamic women who operate different businesses, as often in micro-industrial sectors as sales and services. All the members of the committee operate their businesses with help from credit extended by Fundacion Paraguaya. The members of the committee are tightly organized and their sisterly relations allow them to take joint responsibility for the loans borrowed by the committee. All of the members are working mothers, a fact that binds them further. You can see all of the members of the committee in the attached photo. All the members have their own separate businesses. Even though some have formal jobs, they all operate their businesses in time they have in order to increase their incomes.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

El Comitè “Santa Teresa” se encuentraconformado por un grupo de mujeres muy activas que desarrollan diferentes actividades, tanto en el sector micro industrial como en las ventas y servicios. Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan sus actividades con la ayuda del crédito otorgado por la Fundacion Paraguaya. Las integrantes del comité mantienen una exelente organización y una relacion fraternal lo que les permite asumir solidariamente la responsabilidad por el prestamo otorgado al comite .Todas las integrantes del comité son madres y trabajadoras, por lo que las une ambas cosas. En la fotografia tomada, se encuentran todas las integrantes del comite. Todas las integrantes tienen sus actividades propias, aunque algunas tienen trabajos formales, desarrollan sus emprendimientos en un tiempo extra para acrecentar sus ingresos.

loans.use: The loans that the committee has received from Fundacion Paraguaya have been used to buy various goods, the majority of which are products for resale or for making products for resale.  Among the goods that have been purchased with the loans are meats, sugar, rice, vegetables, dairy products and cheeses, bought mainly to be sold by those committee members who operate groceries, corner shops, etc.  Artisans and those who operate small workshops buy basic goods such as leather, cloth, threads, chemical products, dyes, etc.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es:
Sra. Patricia M., 40, is married to Sr. Victor Velazquez, 63, who works as an electronics technician for a company called Disme. They both contribute to paying household expenses. They have 2 children, a 20-year old who is studying for a degree in Communication Sciences and a 4-year old daughter who will begin elementary school next year.

Patricia has a shop in her house where she sells new and used clothes for children and adults. She also sells women's shoes of different models and designs.

Patricia is applying for a loan to buy used clothing in bundles so that she can get the best price for them and, in turn, increase her own earnings. She can, in this way, meet her commitments with relative ease.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La sra. Patricia M. tiene 40 años y está casada con el Sr. Víctor Velázquez, de 63 años que trabaja como técnico en electrónica para una empresa de nombre Disme, con este ingreso también aporta a la canasta familiar. Tienen 2 hijos, el mayor tiene 20 años y está cursando la carrera de Ciencias de la Comunicación y la hija menor tiene 4 años que comenzará sus estudios primarios el próximo año.

La Sra. Patricia posee en su domicilio un local de ventas de ropas nuevas y usadas para niños y adultos, también tiene para la venta calzados para mujer de diferentes modelos y diseños.

La misma solicita un crédito para la compra de ropas usadas por fardos para obtener de esa manera un precio de costo menor y aumentar su ganancia por la venta de los mismos y de esa manera cumplir con sus compromisos con mayor facilidad.

loans.use: Buy used clothing for children and adults for resale.  Buy women's shoes for resale.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.es:
Sr. Antonio Q., 41, is separated and has a 4-year old daughter, his little companion at work and home. He buys goods for low prices at sales in Ciudad del Este or Asuncion and sells them around Coronel Oviedo.

Antonio has problems walking because of a road accident but that doesn't stop him from selling his merchandise across a wide area or earning what he needs to take care of his daughter or even scraping enough money together to buy a motorcycle to increase his sales. His challenge is to survive, keep the business going and provide opportunities for his daughter.

The requested loan will go to buying merchandise: shoes, shirts, coats. Trust that everything can be better in Paraguay and that you and each of us can help to make it happen.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

El Sr. Antonio Q., tiene 41 años, es separado, con 1 hija, de 4 años de edad, ésta la acompaña en sus labores cotidianas y en el hogar. La venta y compra de las mercaderías lo realiza en ciudad del Este o Asunción, de grandes comercios o remates a muy bajo costo, para luego vender en la zona de Cnel. Oviedo.

El Sr. Antonio tiene problemas físicos para caminar causados por un acccidente carretero, pero eso no es un impedimento para que distribuya sus mercaderías por una amplia zona. y tambien gane lo necesario para cuidar a su hija y hasta comprarse una moto, para agilizar sus ventas. El desafio es sobrevivir, mantener el negocio y ofrecer oportunidades a su hija.

El dinero solicitado será destinado a la compra de mercaderias : zapatos, camisas, abrigos. 3.000.000. G. Confía que todo puede ser mejor en el Paraguay, y eso depende de todos , y de cada uno de nosotros.

loans.use: Buy shoes, shirts and coats for resale.

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
The client, Sr. Francisco S., operates a business in the city of San Ignacio Misiones. He's married and has 3 young children. He and his wife, Elena, own their house; Elena works at a Cooperative. His business is located in his house across from a city high school. He sells cold drinks, groceries, dairy products, cookies, sweets and even pastries which he sells to order for special events. He's operated the business for 5 years and has a well-established customer base that values his shop for the quality of its products.

Francisco is applying for this loan to buy merchandise so that he can increase his inventory and buy supplies for making cakes, an especially good business. The loan will help him to increase his income and improve the lives of his family.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

El Cliente Sr. Francisco S., comerciante de la ciudad de San Ignacio Misiones, casado con 3 hijos menores, viven en casa propia con su esposa Elena, quien es empleada de una Cooperativa, su microempresa se halla ubicado en su domicilio frente a un Colegio de la ciudad donde cuenta con venta de bebidas, comestibles, lácteos, golosinas, dulces, además es repostera los vende sobre pedidos para acontecimientos. En esta actividad posee una antigüedad de 5 años, cuenta con clientela formada reconocida por la calidad de sus productos.

El préstamo solicitado es para compra de mercaderías para incrementar su stock e insumos para la elaboración de tortas, por la buena venta que posee, además le ayudará a incrementar sus ingresos y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for grocery business.

loans.name: Florida

texts.en:
Greetings from Rwanda! Florida is 30 years old, a single mother with four children and three adopted orphans from the 1994 Genocide.

She is a businesswoman who sells bananas and fish in the Rubavu market in Gisenyi. She earns about US$ 100 every month. Through the profits she earns from her business, Florida has been able to build her own house. She is requesting a loan worth 504590 Frws (US$ 925) to boost her business because of the increase in customers.

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: Jorge

texts.es:
Jorge B. Chamorro is 59 years old. He is married to Rufina Caballero de B. and is 57 years old. They have three grown children who are married.

Jorge and his wife own their home, where they have a small tire shop that he was able to set up with his savings.

Currently Jorge provides his services for light vehicles: cars, motorcycles and bicycles. Rufina, his wife, sells "minutas" (local herbs) to help out with the household expenses.

The loan will be used to purchase motorcycle and bicycle accessories.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal Kiva volunteer

El señor Jorge B. Chamorro tiene 59 años de edad y su esposa la señora Rufina Caballero de B. de 57 años de edad tienen 3 hijos todos ya mayores de edad y casados.

Don Jorge y su esposa viven en su casa propia en donde tiene una pequeña gomería, la que monto gracias a un dinero que pudo ahorrar.

Actualmente don Jorge realiza trabajos de gomería para vehículos livianos: autos, motos y bicicletas, doña Rufina su esposa tiene venta de minutas y así ayuda también para el ingreso familiar.

El préstamo solicitado es para la compra de cámaras para motos y bicicletas.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle and bicycle accessories

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
Mario A. is 47 years old. He lives with his wife Zunilda Duarte, who is 28 years old. They have four children, some of whom are school age. They own their home, where they have a small milking yard with 4 cows which produce 50 liters of milk a day.

Mario and his wife are very hard working. They wake up very early very day to milk the cows. Additionally, Mario has an ox cart that he uses to transport sugar cane to the sugar factory in the city of Benjamín Aceval, during the sugar cane harvest. He also uses the cart to deliver firewood to the nearby bakeries. He is a very hardworking man who makes a lot of sacrifices. He must take on all these jobs in order to support his family because the cost of living is higher very day and the money is not enough.

The loan will be used to purchase a motorcycle to deliver the milk.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal Kiva volunteer

El señor Mario Aguliar tiene 47 años de edad vive con su esposa la señora Zunilda Duarte de 28 años de edad, tienen cuatros hijos algunos ya en edad escolar y otros no. Tienen su casa propia en donde cuenta con un pequeño tambo con cuatro vacas lecheras de las que obtiene diariamente 50 litros de leche.

Don Mario y su esposa son muy sacrificados ya que muy temprano se levantan para el ordeñe diario de sus vacas.

Además el señor Mario cuenta con un carro estirado por dos bueyes con el que realiza transporte de caña de azúcar a la Azucarera de la Ciudad de Benjamín Aceval en periodo de zafra y ademas leñas a las panaderías de la zona. Es un hombre muy trabajador y sacrificado, y que debe realizar todas estas actividades para poder solventar los gastos de la familia, ya que la vida esta cada vez más cara y el dinero hoy día ya no alcanza.

El préstamo es para la compra de una moto para repartir su leche.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to deliver milk

loans.name: Inocencia

texts.es:
Inocencia is 44 years old, is married and has 2 children who are minors. They both attend high school.

Inocencia has owned a small clothing store for the past 18 years. She started selling clothing on the streets of several cities. She then decided to set up a small shop in the living room of her house and later she used her savings to build a separate store where she currently sells her merchandise.

She says that it was important to her to have a different activity other than housework that would also be an additional source of income to help with the household expenses.

At her store, she offers a variety of clothing for children, men and women. Her reasonable prices and the payment options she offers have helped her stay in business for so many years. Her main clients are the employees of nearby stores.

The loan she is requesting will be used to purchase merchandise such as: pants, t-shirts, blouses, dress shirts, jeans, skirts and coats.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal Kiva volunteer

La Inocencia tiene 44 años de edad, esta casada, tiene 2 hijos, ambos menores de edad y están cursando la secundaria.

La Sra. Inocencia es propietaria de una mercería hace 18 años, se inició con la venta en forma ambulante de ropas recorriendo varias ciudades. Su pequeña mercería se inició en la sala de su vivienda, luego con unos ahorros empezaron la construcción de un salón comercial, en donde se encuentra la mercería actualmente.

Comenta que para ella era una necesidad la de desarrollar algo más que las tareas del hogar, para así poder aportar a los gastos de la casa.

Ofrece una variedad de ropas, tanto para niños, caballeros y damas, su buen precio y facilidad de pago que da a sus clientes que generalmente son empleados de los comercios de la zona ayudaron para mantener su antigüedad en el mercado.

Solicita el crédito para la compra de mercaderías tales como: pantalones, remeras, blusas, camisas masculinas, jeans, polleras y abrigos.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise such as: pants, t-shirts, blouses, dress shirts, jeans, skirts and coats

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 24 years old, single and for the last year has made a living as a food vendor, selling mostly chips or french fries. She can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Mariam has applied for a loan to buy more supplies for her business.

loans.use: To buy additional supplies for her business.

loans.name: Fardus

texts.en:
Fardus is 47 years old, married and has two children ages 20 and 14. She owns and runs a small general store. She started her business in 1990 and works every day from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. She earns a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Fardus has applied for a loan to buy more items to sell from her store.

loans.use: To increase the inventory in her store.

loans.name: Halima's Muhajirina Group

texts.en:
Halima is 35 years old, married and has a three-year-old child. In 2006, she went into business selling soup and flatbread. Every day she works from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

Halima has applied for a loan to buy more items to sell to her customers. She will share this loan with members of her group, who are in business selling soft drinks, clothes and other items.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell.

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Zainabu is 40 years old, married and has three children between ages 15 and 19. She went into business selling charcoal and chapati, a kind of flatbread. in 2000. Every day, she works from 7 a.m. to Noon at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Zainabu has applied for a loan to buy more charcoal to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell to her customers

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma is 31 years old, married and has two children ages 12 and 5. In 2001, she went into business selling juice and biscuits. Every day, she works from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25.

Fatma has applied for a loan to buy more items to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Ntabanganyimana

texts.en:
Greetings from Rwanda! C. is 31 years old. She is married with three children. 

In 2005, C. started selling fish and charcoal. She earns about $45 every month from her business. She employs seven people. C. is requesting a loan of 300,025 Frw to increase her capital and expand her business. In the future, C. plans to expand her business in another area. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: Increase her working capital and to expand her business

loans.name: Mwadawa's Mungu Tusaidie Group

texts.en:
Mwadawa is 31 years,She is a married woman. She own a beauty salon since in 2005. Every day, she works from 9am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Mwadawa now hopes for a loan to buy more salon items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup Salma and Bahati.

loans.use: To buy more salon items for her business.

loans.name: Kosa

texts.en:
Kosa was born 1951 and she is married. She lives in Pale with her husband. Her husband has a permanent job in the construction industry. His monthly salary is 500 KM. They have two grown children who are not living with them. Kosa spends her free time crocheting different things for furniture and decorations. That is the way that she earns additional income for the family.

This first loan of 1,200 KM will be used to buy crochet thread, because Kosa already has some orders for handicrafts. Her wish is to earn enough money to reconstruct her house.

loans.use: To buy material for handcrafts.

loans.name: Stanimirka

texts.en: Stanimirka is housewife and she lives at Pale. She is not married and she does not have any monthly income for her household. She applied for this loan from our foundation to buy the materials needed for tailoring services, which she already offers to a small number of customers.  Tailoring is the only income generator for her. She wishes to earn and to save enough money to buy additional sewing equipment, which would improve her services. That way she would improve her quality of life.

loans.use: Material for tailoring.

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora is a member of the Gratitud Village Bank. She is an Ecuadoran and has lived five years in the city of Ayacucho due to her husband´s work. Dora is a forty-five-year-old mother of two children. She embroiders decorative articles, such as coverings for native artifacts, which she sells to her friends and acquaintances. She also has many side businesses: she makes cakes and snacks to order, a skill she learned studying at Centro Ocupacional (the Occupation Center); she provides decoration services for children's parties; she sells natural products by catalog, and she has just started a new business of renting out dresses. 

Dora is seeking a loan of 2600 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in different dresses and an industrial oven.

Dora's dream is to have her own home in Ayacucho because she wants to remain living in the city, to expand her business and to run a company that organizes events.

loans.use: To purchase different dresses and an industrial oven

loans.name: Tania Maria

texts.en:
Tania is a member of the Gratitud Village Bank. She is a married, thirty-six-year-old mother of two children. Tania is a primary school teacher and works at a garden in Ayacucho; she also makes handicrafts such as bracelets, doilies, weaves, and embroidery that she sells to her friends and relatives.

Tania and her husband have started a new business this past January, a hardware store situated near the center of the city. They purchase their wholesale products in the city of Lima.

Tania is seeking a loan of 2,000 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to go towards purchasing a motorcycle which would help in running the hardware store. Tania's dream is to own the hardware and make it successful, to have her own garden and to see her children become professionals.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Lisbeth

texts.en:
Lisbeth is a member of the Florecer Village Bank. She has two children, ages 7 years old and 9 months old, that she raises with the help of her mother. Lisbeth and her husband have a restaurant located on a central street near the markets of the city of Ayacucho. In the next few months they will change their location because the current location has a very high rent. She and her husband built up this restaurant with very little capital through hard work. Her husband is the cook with the help of two employees, preparing lunch in the afternoons and soups and a la carte plates for dinner. Lisbeth is responsible for the cash register and at times customer service. Lisbeth and her husband have a project to start a chicken restaurant as well, because their new location is nicer and has more space.

Lisbeth needs a loan of 1,000 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in fish, a restaurant sign, and a new oven.

Lisbeth's dream is to have a larger restaurant, build a home, provide the best educational opportunities for her children and always keep her family together.

loans.use: To purchase fish, a restaurant sign, and a new oven

loans.name: Dragana

texts.en:
Dragana is 37 years old and she lives in Sokolac with her husband and their child, who is in 8 grade of elementary school. Her husband has a permanent job and his monthly salary is 800 KM. Dragana works in her own retail store and generates additional incomes for the household.

This is the first loan that she has taken from our foundation. It is for 600 KM and she intends to use it to buy a vending machine that is used to charge cell phones with additional credit. By buying that machine, her daily sales will increase since she will have the only machine in her area.

loans.use: To buy machine for cell phone.

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina O. is married with two grown kids. She is from Stry where she runs a business selling women’s outer wear and school uniforms in the local market. Galina has been in this business for 10 years. Currently, she has about $2400 in merchandise and about $3000 of gross income.

Galina is requesting a loan of 3000 Grivnas to purchase 30 school uniforms before the upcoming school year. Her vending facility need to be reconstructed and all profits generated this month will be invested in this project. The current loan will not only benefit Galina’s business but will also provide a job for a hired employee working as a salesperson in her kiosk. We believe perfect credit history and determination will help Galina repay this loan on time and succeed in all her entrepreneurial endeavors.

Note: this is a short term “seasonal” loan that will be repaid in two months.

loans.use: To purchase 30 school uniforms

loans.name: Mercedes Huamani Caceres Group

texts.en:
Mercedes, Sonia and Balbina are members of the Florecer Village Bank. Mercedes is a twenty-three-year-old mother of one son; she sells candy at the entrance of a school and also operates a small kiosk where she sells fruit, candies and cancha, a traditional corn snack. Sonia is a forty-year-old single woman who lives with her father and brother; she has a store in their house where she sells groceries, vegetables and fruit. Lastly, Balbina is a thirty-eight-year-old mother of five children; she works with her husband and children at fabric artisan work such as tapestries, walkways, and so forth.

Each of these women is seeking a loan of 400 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in supplies necessary for their businesses (i.e., cookies, caramels, gums, sugar, rice, wool and dyes). All three women dream of expanding their businesses and exporting the products, eventually being able to own their own homes and their own cars.

loans.use: Mercedes, Sonia and Balbina need loans of 400 Peruvian Nuevos Soles each, to invest in cookies, caramels, gums, sugar, rice, wool and dyes.

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is married with a son. She sells sports footwear in the central market in Vinogradovo, Western Ukraine. Location of her kiosk is very favorable as it is right in the center of the marketplace. Nataliya has been in business for six years. Currently, she has about $4000 in inventory and about $800 in income each month.

Financial assistance from Nadiya Ukraine has given Nataliya’s business a good boost. Her profits went up and she could increase on stock. However, her determined nature motivates her to go on and reach even higher goals. Natalya is currently requesting a loan of 2500 Grivnas to increase assorted inventory.

Note: this is a short term “seasonal” loan that will be repaid in 2 months.

loans.use: To increase assortment of inventory

loans.name: Milica

texts.en:
Milica is born 1968 and she is married. Her husband has a permanent job and his monthly salary is 800 KM. They do not have any additional monthly income. They have two children. Milica is a housewife and in her free time she bakes cookies and sweet pies which she sells. In the beginning, she did this just for her family and she helped her friends prepare cookies and pies for special occasions. Later she decided to start a small business baking cookies.

This is her first loan with our foundation in the amount of 600 KM. She will use our loan to buy materials and supplies needed to make the cookies that she will sell. She has permanent customers who already order from her. Her wish is to expand the business to attract more customers and generate additional income for her family.

loans.use: To buy material for making cookies.

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is a married mom of a 12-year-old. Her family lives in Vinogradovo, Transcarpathian region. Nataliya owns a small grocery store and doesn’t face much competition from other store vendors as there are none in her neighborhood. This aspect has become one of the decisive factors of her success. Partnership with Nadiya Ukraine and financial assistance she had received from the organization has become another strong benefit on Nataliya’s way to expansion of her trade.

Nataliya has been in business for eight years. Presently, she has about $5000 in merchandise and get about $1000 in income. Her business is characterized by sustainability and consistent growth. However, Nataliya doesn’t want to stop where she is at. She would like to keep her business running and developing. Nataliya realizes groceries will always be in demand, plus this type of inventory doesn’t depend on seasonal changes which is why she looks into her entrepreneurial future with great optimism. She is requesting a 4000 Grivna loan to increase assorted merchandise and her income as a result.

loans.use: To increase assortment of inventory

loans.name: Celinda's Group

texts.en:
Celina, Olivia and Luz Maria are members of the Gratitud Village Bank. Celina is a married, thirty-one-year-old mother of one son. Celina sells clothing, wallets, accessories, footwear, and other items to friends, acquaintances and relatives on credit. She acquires her products from the city of Lima.

Olivia is married, forty-six years old and the mother of four children. Olivia has a stO. in her house where she sells groceries with the help of her children.

Luz is a married, thirty-five-year-old mother of two children who sells catalog cosmetics and undergarments to her friends and relatives on credit.

Celina, Olivia and Luz need loans of 400, 800 and 800 Peruvian Nuevos Soles respectively (totalling 2000 PEN or approximately 725 USD) to invest in shoes, sweaters, polo shirts, wallets, rice, sugar and undergarments.

Celinda, Olivia and Luz each have a dream to own her own stO., expand her business, provide good educations for her children and have her own home.

loans.use: To invest in shoes, sweaters, polo shirts, wallets, rice, sugar and undergarments

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Sheyla's Group

texts.en:
Sheila and Leticia are members of the Gratitud Village Bank. Sheila is a single, twenty-five-year-old computing student who helps her boyfriend at an Internet center of ten computers at his house, where they also sell candies. Leticia is a married, thirty-year-old mother of two children; she sells catalog cosmetics to her friends, relatives and acquaintances in addition to her household duties and chores.

Shelia and Leticia each is seeking a loan of 600 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in cookies, snacks, gum, cream and perfume. Each dreams of doing well with her business; Sheila hopes to have children one day, and they both dream of seeing their children grow up to become professionals.

loans.use: To invest in supplies for their respective businesses

loans.name: Marisa's Group

texts.en:
Marisa and Romula are members of the Santa Rita Village Bank. Marisa is a married, thirty-three-year-old mother of three children. Marisa has a store in her mother's house where she also lives. She sells groceries like vegetables, fruits, and meat; she's had the business for six years. Romula is a forty-three-year-old mother of five children. Romula has been running a beauty salon in her house for the last four years.

Marisa and Romula need loans of 600 Peruvian Nuevos Soles each to invest in rice, oil, soup, display cases, dyes and liquids for their respective businesses. Each has a dream to expand her business, furnish her house with all the necessities, and provide all the best for her children.

loans.use: To invest in supplies for their respective businesses

loans.name: Berta

texts.en:
Berta is a married, sixty-year-old mother of two children. Berta has a clothing workshop that specializes in making typical clothes such as jumpers, blouses, although her bad vision has prevented her from producing as much as she would like. Furthermore, Berta has a stocked store where she sells groceries, such as vegetables and meat, in her house. She also sells traditional Peruvian food on Sundays.

Berta needs a loan of 1,000 Peruvian Nuevos Soles (PEN) to invest in sugar, rice, milk, eggs and detergents. Through this loan, Berta hopes to realie her dream of expanding her business and thus helping her children. Berta is a member of the Santa Rita Village Bank.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, rice, milk, eggs and other supplies for her store

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.en:
Rosa is a member of the Santa Rita Village Bank and a married, forty-two-year-old mother of six children. Rosa and her husband are artisans who make Ayacuchan altarpieces where customs are staged and holidays of the Ayacucho region are staged. The altarpieces are made of plaster, flour and glue, which are formed into small pieces in wooden cases, an activity that her children help her with. Rosa sells most of her goods in the city of Ayacucho but also to other cities in Peru. Rosa also works as a housekeeper at a hotel for additional income.

Rosa is seeking a loan of 1,000 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in plaster, flour, paint and glue for altarpiece construction. Her dream is to expand her business and be able to help her children become professionals.

loans.use: Rosa needs a loan of 1,000 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in plaster, flour, paint and glue.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita is a member of the Santa Rita Village Bank. She is married, fifty-eight years old and the mother of seven children, two of which live with her in Tambo, two hours away from the city of Ayacucho. Margarita has a store in her house where she sells paint, plastics, tubing, nails and hardware. She purchases these products in Ayacucho, transporting them in rented cars. Her husband also sells hardware in the city of Monterrico in the Ayachuchan Jungle.

Margarita is seeking a loan of 1600 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in more tubing, nails and sackcloth.

Margarita's dream is to improve her business and educate her children to become professionals.

loans.use: To purchase more tubing, nails and sackcloth.

loans.name: Mujeres Pensando En El Futuro Group

texts.en:
Ana Reyes is 57-year-old woman living in Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic. She lives with her husband, and she has three sons who are all married. Ana wants to start her own cafeteria, and she will use this loan to purchase sugar, coffee, tea, bread, butter, mayonnaise, ham, cheese, etc to run her business. She hopes to one day own a house and a motor vehicle to expand her business options.

Ana Reyes is part of a 15-person micro-bank, Mujeres Pensando en el Futuro, which means "Women Thinking in the Future.. Each woman has their own personal business but they unite to pay their loan as a group. The purpose of the group loan is to assist each other in case someone defaults. The Kiva loans will be divided among the group to pay back.

We thank you for your support on behalf of Ana, Mujeres Pensando en el Futuro group, and the entire team at Esperanza International.

loans.use: Ana Reyes will use this loan to purchase products for her cafeteria.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Nueva Vida Group

texts.en:
This Kiva loan will truly be one of a kind.  This group of women, the Nueva Vida group (New Life Group) live in the community of Muñuz, Dominican Republic.  The village is filled with Haitian immigrants and poverty is rampant.  This particular group of women chose to participate in Esperanza International's first-ever trial of the program "40 Days to a New Life".  The program was dedicated to bettering the lives and providing opportunity to women who had been trapped within the cycle of poverty and prostitution.  These women chose to spend 2 hours each day, for forty consecutive days, learning about the Gospel message, God's purpose for their lives, receiving extra medical attention, and learning basic skills such as sewing, making candles, and making jewelry, skills that could be used to start a new business.

Each of these women found themselves in the desperate situation of prostitution as a last resort to feed their children.  Through microfinance, beginning small businesses with $150 loans, these women will be able to find a new way to provide for their children with dignity.  Several have decided to buy and sell clothes, traveling to the nearby city of Santiago to purchase shoes, pants, and shirts for resale in the villages.  Others have chosen to open small shops in front of their homes where they are able to sell juice, bread, cookies, or fried foods while still taking care of their kids.  With their first-ever loan, we at Esperanza are confident that the 40 days of training and this small loan will impact these women's lives forever as they truly take on a new life.

loans.use: To buy different types of clothing for resale, as well as to buy bread, chicken, oils, and fruits to make juices.

loans.name: Las Mujeres Capacidades Group

texts.en:
Justa V. is an ambitious 39-year-old woman living in Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic. She does not have a husband and lives with her two kids (ages 18 and 19), one of whom is married. Justa will use this money to buy chickens and chicken feed so she can have a poultry business. She wishes to keep moving forward with her business and own a big business of her own. She also hopes that her kids will have a house of their own.

Justa V. is part of a 15-person micro-bank, Las Mujeres Capacitadas, which means "Capable Women". Each woman has her own personal business but they unite to pay their loan as a group. The purpose of the group loan is to assist each other in case someone defaults. The Kiva loans will be divided among the group to pay back.

We thank you for your support on behalf of Justa, Las Mujeres Capacitadas group, and the entire team at Esperanza International.

loans.use: Justa Vargas will use this loan to buy products for her poultry business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy rice, sugar, beans, charcoal, coconuts, oil, soap, toilet paper and eggs.

loans.name: Maria Rebeca

texts.es:
Rebeca started her bakery business in order to take care of her household expenses. Since she was only able to rely on her children for a small amount of help, 10 years ago she decided to start a business selling bread and cakes to her acquaintences and neighbors. They started recommending her to others and today she has a large number of clients.

She needs a loan for US $400, which she will repay in 5 months, to buy ingredients and some cooking equipment which she does not have. With your help, Rebeca will be able to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

Rebeca inicio el negocio de reposteria para salir adelante con los gastos de su casa ya que solo cuenta con la ayuda minima de sus hijos, para solventar los gastos de su casa, por lo que deicido comenzar su negocio hace 10 años, vendiendo pan y pasteles, a sus conocidos y vecinos, quienes la fueron recomendando y actualmente ya tiene un gran numero de clientes que la conocen.

Ella necesita un credito por US $400 que pagara en 5 meses para comprar materia prima y algunos accesorios de cocina que le hacen falta. Con tu apoyo Rebeca saldra adelante.

loans.use: Buy ingredients.

loans.name: Khadija's Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
25-year-old Khadija is married with two children, aged 6 and 2. She has a business where she sells clothes, juice and ice cream everyday from 8am to 9pm. She earns a monthly profit of $90 from her sales.

Khadija now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Tatu M..

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Pili

texts.en:
40-year-old Pili is married, with six children between the ages of 2 and 14. Since 2005, she has owned a small general store where she works from 6am to 6pm daily. She earns a monthly profit of $140 from her sales.

Pili now hopes for a loan to buy more merchandise for her business.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for business

loans.name: Pak Asadullah Group
loans.use: To buy clothing supplies

loans.name: Njuma's Wanawake Na Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
40-year-old Njumais is married, with six children between the ages of 4 and 22. Since 2004, she has been working from 7am to 1pm daily at her food vending business. She earns a monthly profit of $250 from her sales.

Njuma now hopes for a loan to buy more food items such as rice, maize flour, meat, vegetables and bananas for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Salma.

loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Mashavu

texts.en:
43-year-old Mashavu is married, with four children between the ages of 13 and 23. Since 2007, she opened a clothes shop where she works daily from 6am to 4pm. She earns a monthly profit of $140 from her sales.

Mashavu now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
35-year-old Hawa is a married with an 18-year-old child. Since 1998, she has worked from 9am to 5pm in her business where she does tailoring, as well as sells clothes and shoes. She earns a monthly profit of $40 from her sales.

In the past, Hawa has taken out one successful loan from PRIDE Tanzania to expand her business. Hawa now hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring materials, shoes and clothes for her business.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Mariam's Wastara Group

texts.en:
21-year-old Mariam has been selling clothes (khanga & vitenge) and perfumes since 2007. She earns a monthly profit of $135 from her sales.

Mariam now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes (khanga & vitenge) for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Mashavu, who also has a business selling snacks, shoes and perfume.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her  stock.

loans.name: Tahiya's Uvumlivu Group

texts.en:
25-year-old Tahiya is a divorcee who became a cake and juice seller in 2008. Every day, she works from 8am to 12pm at her business.

Tahiya now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Mkasi's Tawaqal Group

texts.en:
25-year-old Mkasi is married with two children, aged 6 and 2. Since 2005, she has been a soup vendor where she works at her business from 8am to 12pm daily. She earns a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

Mkasi now hopes for a loan to buy more meat for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who also have businesses as shopkeepers, clothes sellers and food vendors.

loans.use: To buy more meat for her soup business.

loans.name: Asha's Polepole Group

texts.en:
Asha is married with four children between the ages of 6 and 18. Since 2003, she has worked 6am to 8pm daily at her business where she sells food and drinks. She earns a monthly profit of $125 from her sales.

Asha now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business . She will share this loan with her subgroup members who are in the business of selling firewood, charcoal, juice and other foods.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Farashu

texts.en:
43-year-old Farashu is a single mother with four children, aged 16, 14, 12 and 8. Since 2005, she has been working daily from 7am to 6pm, selling charcoal, firewood and coconuts. She earns a monthly profit of $125 from her sales.

Farashu now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal, firewood and coconut for her business.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Mwantatu

texts.en:
45-year-old Mwantatu is married with two children, aged 14 and 12. She has been selling clothes since 2006 and earns a sales profit of approximately $125 per month.

Mwantatu now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes (khanga) for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for business

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
33-year-old Salma is married with three children, aged 12, 10 and 6. Since 2007, Salma has been in the business of selling clothes and juice. She works from 8am to 10pm everyday and earns a monthly profit of approximately $70 from her sales.

Salma now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes (khanga) for her business.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu is 48 years old. She is married, and has four children between the ages of 20 and 27. Tatu sells timber in the local markets, and begins work everyday at 6 AM and ends at 7 PM.

Tatu would like a loan to increase the amount of timber she sells from her business, and also increase the range of her clientele.

loans.use: To buy more timber materials for her business.

loans.name: Batuli

texts.en:
Batuli is 23 years old. She has two children, ages 2 and 4. Batuli sells both charcoal and chapatti, a kind of cake. She began her business in 2008, and works everyday from 6 AM to 6 PM.

Batuli hopes that with her loan, she can purchase more charcoal and continue to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is 28 years old. She has two children, ages 10 and 14. In 2005, she began her own clothing and perfume sales shop. In one month, Halima earns a profit of around $65 from her sales.

Halima would now like to request a loan to increase her inventory of clothes, and expand her business range and clientele.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Kazisa's Hatutaki Uvivu Group

texts.en:
Kazisa is 45 years old. She is married, and has one child, who is 29 years old. She owns and runs a small food shop, which she opened in 2005. Everyday, Kazisa works from 6 AM to 10 PM, and earns a total of around $40 a month from her business.

In the past, Kazisa has successfully completed two loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Kazisa now hopes that another loan will allow her to purchase additional items, such as rice, maize, sugar, and soap for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have business in selling snacks and porridges.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Fatma's Tusongembele Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 27 years old. Her husband has passed away, leaving her with 3 children, aged 11, 14, and 15. Fatma entered the charcoal and cake industry in 2006. She begins work everyday at 6 AM and ends at 6 PM, and earns around $20 a month in profits from her business.

In the past, Fatma has successfully completed one loan from BRAC Tanzania. She used the money to expand her business, and she would like to continue to do so. She will also share her loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in food, charcoal, and firewood sales.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and charcoal to increase her stock.

loans.name: Amina's Umoja Ni Nguvu Group

texts.en:
Amina is 36 years old. She is married, and has 5 children between the ages of 15 and 25. Amina sells juices, fish, and bread. She began her business in 2004, and begins work everyday at 6 AM and ends at 6 PM. She earns a monthly profit of around $35 from her sales.

In the past, Amina has successfully completed two loans from BRAC Tanzania. She has used the money to expand her business, and purchase more items for her inventory. In addition, she will also share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with charcoal, clothes, and batik making.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her stock

loans.name: Amina's Umoja Ni Nguvu Group

texts.en:
Amina is 24 years old. She is married, and has one child, aged 2 months. Amina runs a salon and works in a hotel. She began in 2006, and begins everyday at 6 AM and ends at 6 PM. She earns a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

In the past, Amina has successfully completed one loan from BRAC Tanzania. She is hoping to continue her business expansion, and increase the range of items she sells. She will also share her loan with a fellow subgroup member, who also sells clothes at her own business.

loans.use: To buy more salon items for her business.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Mrs. Ly K., 61, and her husband, Mr. Im Hing, 64, live on an island in the Mekong River near Phnom Penh. They were married in 1962 and have seven children, three sons and four daughters. Five of their children are now married and live outside the family home. The other two children live with them in their custody; one weaves silk at home.

Mrs. Ly has been a silk weaver since 1979, a skill she learned from her mother. Mr. Im has been a commune officer since 1979. Ly sells her finished products to a reseller in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma is 25 years old, married, and has three children aged 1, 4, and 6. Fatma sells clothes (called “khanga”), juice, and foods. She began her business in 2004. Everyday, Fatma works from 6 AM to 8 PM and earns a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Fatma has already successfully completed one loan from BRAC Tanzania, and has continued to expand her business since then. She would like to continue to increase the range of items she sells, and is hoping to accomplish this through another loan.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her stock

loans.name: At

texts.en:
Mrs. At P., 54, and her husband, Mr. San Thuy, live on an island in the Mekong River near Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have eight children, four sons and four daughters. Two of their children are married, one of whom lives in the family home. Two of their children are construction workers, one daughter is a weaver, and the youngest one is in school and weaves silk when she has free time from her studies.

Mrs. At has been a silk weaver for many years, a skill she learned from her mother. At also sells vegetables and fish in the village when she is free from her weaving business. Mr. Thuy has been a motor taxi driver for over twenty years. At sells her finished products to a reseller, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. The couple lives in an old house and needs some money to build a new house for their family. Thus, she is requesting a loan of 1200 USD to build a new house for her family.

loans.use: To build a house for her family

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mrs. Phalla N. (shown in the picture with her mother and her son), 26, and her husband were married in 2004. The couple lives with Phalla's parents along National Road #1 about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh and have two children, one son and one daughter.

Mrs. Phalla has been selling fruit since 2006. She buys them from farmers in her village for resale at her shop in front of her house and some at Kor Ky market. Her husband has full-time employment in Phnom Penh. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to drive to work (and thus save money on the motor taxi) and to purchase fruit for resale.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle and wholesale fruit

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is 25 years old. She is married, and has two children, aged 4 and 3. Fatima began to vend food in 2006. She works everyday from 7 AM to 12 PM, earning a monthly profit of about $20 from her sales.

In the past, Fatima has successfully completed one loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Fatima would like to request another loan to purchase more food items, such as juice and eggs, to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Bunchhoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Bunchhoeun C., 26, and his wife, Mrs. Boravy Van were married in 2004. They live with their parents along National Road #1 about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh with their one son.

Mr. Bunchhoeun has been a motor taxi driver for four years. He carries people from his village to Phnom Penh and back; his wife is a garment factory worker. Currently his motorcycle is very old and often breaks down, so he wants to purchase a replacement but lacks the money. He is seeking a loan of 700 USD to purchase a new motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle

loans.name: Sina

texts.en:
Mrs. Sina B., 42, and her husband, Mr. Phally Yim, 45, who live along National Road #1 about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1982 and have one daughter who is a garment factory worker. Her husband has been a mason since 1982.

Mrs. Sina has been selling fruit since 2006. She buys her fruit wholesale from farmers in her village and some from fruit market in Phnom Penh for resale at Kandal market in Phnom Penh. Currently, Sina needs some money to buy fruit "in contract," meaning that to secure a better wholesale price she needs to pay them before the fruit is harvested. To do so, Sina is requesting a loan of 1000 USD to purchase fruit in contract for next season.

loans.use: To purchase fruit in contract for next season

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
Asia is 25 years old. She entered the cosmetics industry in 2007. Everyday, she works from 10 AM to 4 PM at her business, selling soap and personal products for a monthly profit of about $30 from sales.

In the past, Asia has successfully completed two loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Asia now hopes she can complete another loan to purchase more items and expand the range of her business and clientele.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of cosmetics

loans.name: Mayasa

texts.en:
Mayasa is 35 years old, married, and has 8 children, all between the ages of 9 and 16. In 2003, she began to sell fish. Everyday, she begins work at 10 AM and ends at 1 PM. She earns a monthly profit of around $25 from her business.

Mayasa has already successfully completed one loan from BRAC Tanzania. She used her initial loan to expand her business, and is now requesting a second loan with the hope that she can continue to purchase fish to support her business and family.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for her business

loans.name: Mwema's Nyota Njema Group

texts.en:
Mwema is 27 years old. She is married, and has three children between the ages of 9 and 11. She has been a tailor since 2003. Everyday, Mwema begins work at 7:30 AM and ends at 4 PM. She earns a profit of about $20 a month from her business.

In the past, Mwema has successfully completed a loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Mwema now hopes to request another loan in order to purchase more items for her business. She will also share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in food, charcoal, and clothing services.

loans.use: To buy more tailoling items and clothes for her business.

loans.name: Amina's Riziki Popote Group

texts.en:
Amina is 29 years old. She is married, and has two children, aged 5 and 3. Amina became a clothes and cosmetics vendor in 2006. Everyday, she begins work at 6 AM and ends at 6 PM. She earns a total of about $25 in profits per month.

In the past, Amina has successfully completed one loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She is now hoping to purchase more clothes, and expand her inventory of cosmetics. In addition, she will share her loan with a fellow subgroup member, who also has a business in bed sheets and clothing.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora is a widowed, 42-year-old mother of two children. Leonora sells various clothing, specializing in typical clothing of the region. She acquires her products from the regional fairs of Ayacucho and sells her products in the city of Concepción, seven hours away from Ayacucho. She also purchases cereals, small animals, etc. from Concepción and resells them to middlemen in Ayacucho. During her absence, her older son is in charge of her younger son. Furthermore, she has land in the city of Pampas where she cultivates reeds and avocados that she sells to middlemen.

Leonora is a member of the Santa Rita Village Bank. She needs a loan of 1,000 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in jumpers, blankets, blouses, and pants.

Leonora's dream is to produce more on her land and to educate her children to become professionals.

loans.use: to invest in jumpers, blankets, blouses and pants

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a single, 27-year-old mother of one son. Maria travels to the Ayacuchan Jungle where she sells vegetables, cereal, etc. that she acquires from the supply markets of Ayacucho. She usually buys her products on Fridays and re-sells them on Saturdays and Sundays in the city of Puerto Cocos. Furthermore, Maria sells catalog cosmetics to her friends and relatives.

Maria is a member of the Nueva Vida Village Bank. She needs a loan of 2,500 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in celery, carrots, various cereals, onions, and tomatoes for re-sale.

Maria's dream is to have her own grocery store and to move forward with her son.

loans.use: to invest in celery, carrots, various cereals, onions, and tomatoes

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Gianina Victoria

texts.en:
Gianina is a single, 27-year-old mother of one child. Gianina has a partner who has a refill and auto store and they acquire their products from Lima. Furthermore, the two have a mechanics workshop for automobiles, run with the help of four employees. Also, Gianina has returned to her studies of Law.

Gianina is a member of the Nueva Vida Village Bank. She needs a loan of 1,000 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in cases of different models.

Gianina's dream is to finish her career studies, to have more branches outsides of the city of Ayacucho, and to be able to afford a good education for her son.

loans.use: to invest in cases of different models

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Paulina Julia

texts.en:
Julia is a married, 63-year-old mother of six children. Julia and her husband have a carpentry shop in their house, located in the "April 16" Housing Development, with the help of her sons as well. Her carpentry shop requires machinery for different contracts and different clients. Julia also makes gelatins and other homemaD. products that she sells in her house and at the market.

Julia is a member of the Nueva Vida Village Bank. She needs a loan of 2,500 Peruvian Nuevos Soles that she will invest in wood, laquer, etc. 

Julia's dream is to educate her children, to move forward, and to improve her life.

loans.use: invest in wood, laquer, etc.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly is from the Quinua District located an hour away from the city of Ayacucho. She is a separated, 32-year-old mother of two children. Nelly lives in her parents' house, but does not have the help of her children's father. She has a store where she sells groceries, fruit, and drinks. Furthermore, Nelly has a car used for public transportation with the help of a driver.

Nelly is a member of Los Libertadores Village Bank. She needs a loan of 2,500 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in rice, sugar, beer, detergent, and candies to further expand her business.

Nelly's dream is to construct her house, to have another car, and that her children may become professionals.

loans.use: to invest in rice, sugar, beer, detergent, and candies

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Segundina

texts.en:
Segundina is of the Quinua District located an hour from the city of Ayacucho. She is a married, 34-year-old mother of three children. She has a small grocery store at a rented location, a business she has recently started and little by little supplied. Furthermore, Segundina sells shoes, sandals, etc. on Sundays at the regional fair of the district. Her spouse is a veterinary technician and also sells medicine.

Segundina is a member of Los Libertadores Village Bank. She needs a loan of 1,000 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to invest in rice, sugar, oil, eggs, and candies to further expand her business.
